[[File:Un-honduras.png|thumb|A map of [[Honduras]].]]
'''[[Honduras]]''' is a country in [[Central America]]. Honduras borders the [[Caribbean Sea]] and the North [[Pacific Ocean]]. [[Guatemala]] lies to the west, [[Nicaragua]] south east and [[El Salvador]] to the south west. Honduras is the second largest Central American republic, with a total area of {{convert|112,890|km2}}.
Honduras has a {{convert|700|km|adj=on|abbr=off|sp=us}} Caribbean coastline extending from the mouth of the [[RÃ­o Motagua]] in the west to the mouth of the [[RÃ­o Coco]] in the east, at [[Cape Gracias a Dios]]. The {{cvt|922|km}} southeastern side of the triangle is a land border with Nicaragua. It follows the RÃ­o Coco near the Caribbean Sea and then extends southwestward through mountainous terrain to the [[Gulf of Fonseca]] on the Pacific Ocean. The southern apex of the triangle is a {{cvt|153|km}} coastline on the Gulf Fonseca, which opens onto the Pacific Ocean. In the west there are two land borders: with [[El Salvador]] as {{cvt|342|km|mi|adj=mid|long}} and with Guatemala as {{cvt|256|km|mi|adj=mid|long}}.
==Topography== [[Image:Honduras Topography.png|thumb|550px|Honduras' topography.]] Honduras has three distinct topographical regions: an extensive interior highland area and two narrow coastal lowlands. The interior, which constitutes approximately 80 percent of the country's terrain, is mountainous. The larger Caribbean lowlands in the north and the Pacific lowlands bordering the Gulf of Fonseca are characterized by [[alluvial plains]].
===Interior highlands=== The interior highlands are the most prominent feature of Honduran topography. This mountain area makes up about 80% of the country's area, and is home to the majority of the population. Because the rugged terrain has made the land difficult to traverse and equally difficult to cultivate, this area has not been highly developed. The soil here is poor: Honduras lacks the rich volcanic ash found in other Central American countries. Until the early 20th century, the highland economy consisted primarily of mining and livestock.
In the west, Honduras' mountains blend into the mountain ranges of Guatemala. The western mountains have the highest peaks, with the Pico CongolÃ³n at an elevation of {{convert|2,500|m|ft|0}} and the [[Cerro Las Minas]] at {{cvt|2,850|m|ft|0}}. The Honduran border with El Salvador crosses the peak of [[Cerro El Pital]], the highest point in El Salvador at over {{cvt|2700|m|ft|0}}. These mountains are woodland covered with mainly pine forests.
In the east, the mountains merge with those in Nicaragua. Although generally not as high as the mountains near the Guatemalan border, the eastern ranges possess some high peaks, such as the MontaÃ±a de la Flor at {{cvt|2,300|m|ft|0}}, El BoquerÃ³n (Monte El BoquerÃ³n) at {{cvt|2,485|m|ft|0}}, and Pepe Bonito at {{cvt|2,435|m|ft|0}}.
One of the most prominent features of the interior highlands is a depression that runs from the Caribbean Sea to the Gulf of Fonseca. This depression splits the country's [[cordillera]]s into eastern and western parts and provides a relatively easy transportation route across the isthmus. Widest at its northern end near San Pedro Sula, the depression narrows as it follows the upper course of the RÃ­o Humuya. Passing first through Comayagua and then through narrow passes south of the city, the depression widens again as it runs along the border of El Salvador into the Gulf of Fonseca.
[[Image:Honduras econ 1983.jpg|thumb|550px|A economic activity map of Honduras, 1983.]] [[Image:Honduras land 1983.jpg|thumb|550px|A land use map of Honduras, 1983.]] Scattered throughout the interior highlands are numerous flat-floored valleys, at {{convert|300|to|900 |meters}} in elevation, which vary in size. The floors of the large valleys provide sufficient grass, shrubs, and dry woodland to support livestock and, in some cases, commercial agriculture. [[Subsistence agriculture]] has been relegated to the slopes of the valleys, with the limitations of small-sized holdings, primitive technology, and low productivity that traditionally accompany hillside cultivation. Villages and towns, including the capital, Tegucigalpa, are tucked in the larger valleys.
Vegetation in the interior highlands is varied. Much of the western, southern, and central mountains are open woodland; supporting pine forest interspersed with some oak, scrub, and grassy clearings. The ranges toward the east are primarily continuous areas of dense, broad-leaf evergreen forest. Around the highest peaks, remnants of dense rainforest that formerly covered much of the area are still found.
===Caribbean lowlands===
This area of river valleys and coastal plains, which most Honduras call "the north coast," or simply "the coast," has traditionally been Honduras's most exploited region. The central part of the Caribbean lowlands, east of La Ceiba, is a narrow coastal plain only a few kilometers wide.
To the east and west of this section the Caribbean lowlands widen and in places extend inland a considerable distance along broad river valleys. The broadest river valley, along the [[RÃ­o UlÃºa]] near the Guatemalan border, is Honduras's most developed area. Both [[Puerto CortÃ©s]], the country's largest port, and [[San Pedro Sula]], Honduras's industrial capital, are located here, as is [[La Ceiba]], the third largest city in the country.
To the east, near the Nicaraguan border, the Caribbean lowlands broaden to an extensive area known as [[La Mosquitia]]. Unlike the western part of the Caribbean lowlands, the Mosquitia is Honduras's least-developed area. Underpopulated and culturally distinct from the rest of the country, the area consists of inland savannah with swamps and [[mangrove]] near the coast. During times of heavy rainfall, much of the savannah area is covered by shallow water, making transportation by means other than a shallow-draft boat almost impossible.
More than 46 ''campesinos'' from the AguÃ¡n Valley, in the far north-east of Honduras, have either been killed or have disappeared since the 2009 coup.<ref name=nation> {{cite news |title= WikiLeaks Honduras: US Linked to Brutal Businessman |url= https://www.thenation.com/article/wikileaks-honduras-us-linked-brutal-businessman/ |date=October 21, 2011 |author=Dana Frank |publisher=The Nation }}</ref> In the 1970s, government policy encouraged agricultural cooperatives and collectives to establish themselves in the lightly-populated area, but after 1992 government policy favored privatization.<ref name=nation /> One of the biggest beneficiaries of the new policy and one of the richest men in Honduras,<ref> {{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/local/obituaries/la-me-miguel-facusse-20150624-story.html |title=Miguel Facusse dies at 90; colorful, ruthless Honduran tycoon |date=June 23, 2015 |author=Tracy Wilkinson }} </ref> [[Miguel FacussÃ© Barjum|Miguel FacussÃ©]], owned some {{cvt|22,000|acres|ha}} in the lower AguÃ¡n, which he planted in African palms for his palm oil venture.
===Pacific lowlands=== The smallest geographic region of Honduras, the Pacific lowlands, is a strip of land averaging {{cvt|25|km|mi|spell=in|disp=x| wide (|)}} on the north shore of the Gulf of Fonseca. The land is flat, becoming swampy near the shores of the gulf, and is composed mostly of alluvial soils washed down from the mountains. The gulf is shallow and the water rich in fish and [[mollusk]]s. Mangroves along the shore make [[shrimp]] and [[shellfish]] particularly abundant by providing safe and abundant breeding areas amid their extensive networks of underwater roots.
Several islands in the gulf fall under Honduras's jurisdiction. The two largest, Zacate Grande and El Tigre, are eroded volcanoes, part of the chain of volcanoes that extends along the Pacific coast of Central America. Both islands have volcanic cones more than {{cvt|700|meters}} in elevation that serve as landmarks for vessels entering Honduras's Pacific.
===Islands=== {{See also|List of islands of Honduras}}
Honduras controls a number of islands as part of its offshore territories. In the Caribbean Sea, the islands of RoatÃ¡n (Isla de RoatÃ¡n), Utila, and Guanaja together form the ''[[Islas de la BahÃ­a]]'' (Bay Islands), one of the eighteen departments into which Honduras is divided. [[RoatÃ¡n]], the largest of the three islands, is {{convert|50|by|5|km|mi|sp=us|abbr=on}}. The Islas de la BahÃ­a archipelago also has a number of smaller islands, among them the islets of Barbareta (Isla Barbareta), Santa Elena (Isla Santa Elena), and Morat (Isla Morat).
Farther out in the Caribbean are the Islas Santanillas, formerly known as Swan Islands. A number of small islands and keys can be found nearby, among them Cayos Zapotillos and Cayos Cochinos. In the Gulf of Fonseca, the main islands under Honduran control are El Tigre, Zacate Grande (Isla Zacate Grande), and ExposiciÃ³n (Isla ExposiciÃ³n).
==Climate== [[File:Honduras KÃ¶ppen.svg|250px|thumb|[[KÃ¶ppen climate classification system|KÃ¶ppen climate types]] of Honduras]]
The climatic types of each of the three physiographic regions differ. The Caribbean lowlands have a tropical wet climate with consistently high temperatures and humidity, and rainfall fairly evenly distributed throughout the year. The Pacific lowlands have a tropical wet and dry climate with high temperatures but a distinct dry season from November through April. The interior highlands also have a distinct dry season, but, as is characteristic of a tropical highland climate, temperatures in this region decrease as elevation increases.
Unlike in more northerly latitudes, temperatures in the tropics vary primarily with elevation instead of with the season. Land below {{convert|1,000|m|ft|0|sp=us}} is commonly known as ''tierra caliente'' (hot land), between {{cvt|1000|and|2000|m|ft|0}} as ''tierra templada'' (temperate land), and above {{cvt|2,000|m|ft|0}} as ''tierra frÃ­a'' (cold land). Both the Caribbean and Pacific lowlands are ''tierra caliente'', with daytime highs averaging between {{convert|28|and|32|Â°C|Â°F|1}} throughout the year.
In the Pacific lowlands, April, the last month of the dry season, brings the warmest temperatures; the rainy season is slightly cooler, although higher humidity during the rainy season makes these months feel more uncomfortable. In the Caribbean lowlands, the only relief from the year-round heat and humidity comes during December or January when an occasional strong cold front from the north (a ''norte'') brings several days of strong northwest winds and slightly cooler temperatures.
The interior highlands range from tierra templada to tierra frÃ­a. [[Tegucigalpa]], in a sheltered valley and at an elevation of {{cvt|1,000|m|ft|0}}, has a pleasant climate, with an average high temperature ranging from {{convert|30|Â°C}} in April, the warmest month, to {{convert|25|Â°C}} in January, the coolest. Above {{convert|2,000|m|ft|0|sp=us}}, temperatures can fall to near freezing at night, and frost sometimes occurs.
Rain falls year round in the Caribbean lowlands but is seasonal throughout the rest of the country. Amounts are copious along the north coast, especially in the Mosquitia, where the average rainfall is {{convert|2,400|mm|in|1|sp=us}}. Nearer San Pedro Sula, amounts are slightly less from November to April, but each month still has considerable precipitation. The interior highlands and Pacific lowlands have a dry season, known locally as "summer," from November to April. Almost all the rain in these regions falls during the "winter," from May to September. Total yearly amounts depend on surrounding topography; Tegucigalpa, in a sheltered valley, averages only {{cvt|1,000|mm|in|1}} of precipitation.
=== Hurricanes === Honduras lies within the hurricane belt, and the Caribbean coast is particularly vulnerable to hurricanes or tropical storms that travel inland from the Caribbean. Hurricane Francelia in 1969 and Tropical Storm Alleta in 1982 affected thousands of people and caused extensive damage to crops. [[Hurricane Fifi]] in 1974 killed more than 8,000 and destroyed nearly the entire banana crop.
In 1998 [[Hurricane Mitch]] became the most deadly hurricane to strike the Western Hemisphere in the last two centuries. This massive hurricane not only battered the Honduran coastline, but engulfed nearly the entire country with its powerful winds and torrential downpours. Throughout Central America, Mitch claimed in excess of 11,000 lives, with thousands of others missing. More than three million people were either homeless or severely affected. Most Hurricanes occasionally form over the Pacific and move north to affect southern Honduras, but Pacific storms are generally less severe and their landfall rarer.
On September 4, 2007, [[Hurricane Felix]] made landfall at Honduras and Nicaragua, as a Category 5 hurricane. In November 2008, [[Hurricane Paloma]], along with the [[October 2008 Central America floods]], left at least 60 people dead and more than 300,000 in need of assistance.<ref>{{cite web |agency= United Nations News Service |publisher=ReliefWeb |date= November 18, 2008 |accessdate= May 21, 2015 |title= Hondurans face many months of struggle after deadly floods, UN aid wing says |url= http://reliefweb.int/report/honduras/hondurans-face-many-months-struggle-after-deadly-floods-un-aid-wing-says }}</ref>
==Hydrography== {{Main article|Rivers of Honduras}}
[[File:Barra-de-los-rios-ulua y chamelecon.jpg|thumb|400px|The [[UlÃºa River]] as seen from the air. The Ulua is perhaps the most economically important river in Honduras.]] Honduras is a water-rich country. The most important river in Honduras is the [[UlÃºa River|UlÃºa]], which flows {{cvt|400|km}} to the Caribbean through the economically important Valle de Sula. Numerous other rivers drain the interior highlands and empty north into the Caribbean. These other rivers are important, not as transportation routes, but because of the broad fertile valleys they have produced. The [[Choluteca River]] runs south from [[Tegucigalpa]] through [[Choluteca, Choluteca|Choluteca]] and out at the [[Gulf of Fonseca]].
Rivers also define about half of Honduras's international borders. The [[RÃ­o GoascorÃ¡n]], flowing to the [[Gulf of Fonseca]], and the [[RÃ­o Lempa]] define part of the border between El Salvador and Honduras. The [[RÃ­o Coco|Coco River]] marks about half of the border between Nicaragua and Honduras.
Despite an abundance of rivers, large bodies of water are rare. Lago de Yojoa, located in the west-central part of the country, is the sole natural lake in Honduras. This lake is twenty-two kilometers long and at its widest point measures fourteen kilometers. Several large, brackish lagoons open onto the Caribbean in northeast Honduras. These shallow bodies of water allow limited transportation to points along the coast.

==Natural resources== The natural resources include: [[timbers]], [[gold]], [[silver]], [[copper]], [[lead]], [[zinc]], [[iron ore]], [[antimony]], [[coal]], [[fish]], and [[hydropower]] from the mountain rivers.
==Natural hazards== Frequent mild [[earthquake]]s, damaging [[hurricanes]], and floods along the [[Caribbean]] coast are examples of Honduran natural hazards.
==Environmental issues== Deforestation poses a particular problem for Honduras; the goals of conserving endangered natural resources and promoting economic development has often been quite difficult to combine, which has resulted in conflicting policies that fail to protect forests. Honduras has suffered the greatest percentage loss of forest cover of any country in [[Latin America]]. The forests in Honduras are an important source of economic resources to finance government programs. The tropical forests in Honduras are diminishing rapidly due to poverty in the country. The majority of the population of Honduras see the forests as an obstacle to the expansion of ranching and agricultural activities, ignoring the significance that forests have for the society through protection of fauna, soils, recreation, purification of air, and the regulation of water sources. The urban population is also increasing rapidly over the years, which means that it has led to the clearing of land for farming and the farming of marginal soils in rural areas, as well as to uncontrolled development in the fringes of urban areas. Illegal logging is also a major problem in Honduras. The majority of the production of timber in the country is illegal. According to the [[Center for International Policy]] and the [[Environmental Investigation Agency]], the timber trade corruption involves politicians, timber companies, bureaucrats, mayors, and even the police. All of these factors contribute to deforestation and consequently to soil erosion. According to the [[Food and Agriculture Organization]], Honduras lost 59,000 hectares of forest per year between 1990 and 2000. Deforestation in regions dominated by tropical dry forests has advanced faster than regions dominated by other types of forests. Tropical dry forests have lower species richness compared to moist forests. However, tropical dry forests possess higher levels of endemic species, greater utility for humans, and also have a higher human population density. The effects of deforestation are more noticeable during tropical storms and hurricanes. In 1998, [[Hurricane Mitch]] killed thousands and also caused damage to the country. According to aerial surveys following the storm, mudslides were worst in deforested areas than forested areas. Many endangered species live in the forests of Honduras, and they may soon be extinct if deforestation continues. The climate has also changed because of the lack of trees in Honduras. This has caused the growing season for farmers to be shortened. The ground in deforested areas is absorbing all the water as well. The largest source of freshwater in Honduras, [[Lake Yojoa]], is on the verge of turning into a swamp. This is due to the high rate of pollution and logging as well. Lake Yojoa is also being polluted by heavy metals from local mining activities. Lake Yojoa is home to more than 400 species of birds, but the area surrounding the Lake is suffering from deforestation and water pollution. However, not only Lake Yojoa is being polluted with heavy metals, nearby rivers and streams are also being polluted.
<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Tucker |first1=Christine |title=Comparative Spatial Analyses of Forest Conservation and Change in Honduras and Guatemala |journal=Conservation & Society |date=January-June 2005 |volume=3 |issue=1 |page=174-200}}</ref>
<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Bass |first1=Joby |title=Message in the Plaza: Landscape, Landscaping, and Forest Discourse in Hondur |journal=Geographical Review |date=Oct., 2005 |volume=95 |issue=4 |page=556-577}}</ref>

{{Infobox islands | name = Saint Lucia | image_name = Saint Lucia geography map en.png | image_caption = Map of Saint Lucia | image_size = | map_image = Karibik St Lucia Position.png | map_caption = | native_name = | native_name_link = | nickname = ''Helen of the West Indies'' | location = [[Caribbean Sea]] | coordinates = {{coord|13|53|N|60|58|W|display=inline}} | archipelago = [[Windward Islands]] | total_islands = | major_islands = | area_km2 = 616 | length_km = | width_km = | coastline_km = 158 | highest_mount = [[Mount Gimie]] | elevation_m = 950 | country = Saint Lucia | country_admin_divisions_title = | country_admin_divisions = | country_admin_divisions_title_1 = | country_admin_divisions_1 = | country_admin_divisions_title_2 = | country_admin_divisions_2 = | country_largest_city = [[Castries]] | country_largest_city_population = 10,634 | population = 160,765 | population_as_of = 2005 | density_km2 = 260.98 | ethnic_groups = [[African diaspora|African]] 82.5%, [[Mulatto]] 11.9%, [[East Indians|East Indian]] 2.4%, [[White people|White]] 1.0%, Other or unspecified 3.1% | additional_info = }} [[File:St Lucia map.png|thumb|300px |Map of Saint Lucia.]] '''[[Saint Lucia]]''' is one of many small land masses composing the insular group known as the [[Windward Islands]]. Unlike large limestone areas such as [[Florida]], [[Cuba]], and the [[Yucatan Peninsula]], or the [[Bahamas]], which is a small island group composed of coral and sand, St. Lucia is a typical Windward Island formation of [[volcanic]] rock that came into existence long after much of the region had already been formed. St. Lucia's physical features are notable. Dominated by high peaks and rain forests in the interior, the {{convert|616|km2|sqmi|abbr=off|sp=us|adj=on}} island is known for the twin peaks of [[Gros Piton]] and [[Petit Piton]] on the southwestern coast, its soft sandy beaches, and its magnificent natural harbors. [[Mount Gimie]], the highest peak, is located in the central mountain range and rises to {{convert|958|m|ft|0|sp=us}} above sea level, a contrast that is also evident in the abrupt climatic transition from coastal to inland areas. The steep terrain also accentuates the many rivers that flow from central St. Lucia to the Caribbean. Fertile land holdings, which support banana farming, are scattered throughout the island. St. Lucia has a tropical, humid climate moderated by northeast trade winds that allow for pleasant year-round conditions. Mean annual temperatures range from {{convert|26|Â°C|1}} to {{convert|32|Â°C|1}} at sea level and drop to an average of {{convert|13|Â°C|1}} in the mountain peaks. The abundant annual rainfall accumulates to approximately {{convert|2000|mm|in|1|sp=us}}, with most precipitation occurring during the June to December wet season. Hurricanes are the most severe climatic disturbance in this area and have been known to cause extensive damage. Although St. Lucia has historically been spared from serious hurricane destruction, [[Hurricane Allen]] decimated the agricultural sector and claimed nine lives in 1980. More recently, in 2010, Hurricane Tomas claimed seven lives and also caused extensive agricultural damage, particularly to the island's burgeoning cocoa crop. ==General== ===Location=== Co-ordinates: {{coord|13.9|N|61.0|W|type:isle|display=inline, title}} Saint Lucia is in the [[Caribbean]], an island between the [[Caribbean Sea]] and [North Atlantic Ocean], north of [[Saint Vincent and the Grenadines|Saint Vincent]] and north-west of [[Barbados]]. The capital city of Saint Lucia is [[Castries]], where about one third of the population lives. Major towns include [[Gros Islet]], [[SoufriÃ¨re, Saint Lucia|SoufriÃ¨re]] and [[Vieux Fort]]. ===Measurements=== * ''total area:'' 616 kmÂ² * ''length:'' 43.5 km * ''width:'' 22.5 km * ''comparative area:'' The same as [[Toronto]] or 3.5 times the size of [[Washington, DC]] * ''Land boundaries:'' 0 km * ''Coastline:'' 158 km ===Maritime claims=== * {{convert|200|nmi|km mi|1|lk=in}} * ''contiguous zone:'' {{convert|24|nmi|km mi|1}} * ''exclusive economic zone:'' {{convert|200|nmi|km mi|1}} * ''territorial sea:'' {{convert|12|nmi|km mi|1}} ==Climate== Saint Lucia is in the tropical zone, although its climate is moderated by northeast trade winds. Since it is fairly close to the equator, the temperature does not fluctuate much between winter and summer. The dry season is from December to June, and the rainy season is from June to November. Average daytime temperatures are around
{{convert|29|C|F|1|abbr=on}}, and average nighttime temperatures are around {{convert|18|C|F|1|abbr=on}}. Average annual rainfall ranges from {{convert|1300|mm|1|abbr=on}} on the coast to {{convert|3810|mm|0|abbr=on}} in the mountain rainforests. ==Terrain== Volcanic and mountainous with some broad, fertile valleys. ===Elevation extremes=== * ''lowest point:'' Caribbean Sea 0 m * ''highest point:'' Mt. Gimie 950 m [[File:sulfur spring st lucia.JPG|thumb|Sulfur spring.]] ===Natural resources=== [[Forests]], sandy beaches [[mineral]]s ([[pumice]]), [[mineral spring]]s, [[Geothermal (geology)|geothermal]] potential. ===Land use=== * ''Arable land:'' 8% * ''permanent crops:'' 21% * ''permanent pastures:'' 5% * ''forests and woodland:'' 13% * ''other:'' 53% (1993 est.) * ''Irrigated land:'' {{convert|10|kmÂ²|0|abbr=on}} (1993 est.) == Political map == === Quarters === {{main|Quarters of Saint Lucia}} [[File:Sainte-Lucie - districts numÃ©rotÃ©s.png|thumb|Quarters of Saint Lucia]] The island of Saint Lucia is divided into 11 quarters: # [[Anse la Raye Quarter|Anse la Raye]] # [[Canaries Quarter|Canaries]] # [[Castries Quarter|Castries]] # [[Choiseul Quarter|Choiseul]] # [[Dennery Quarter|Dennery]] # [[Central Forest Reserve (Saint Lucia)|Forest Reserve]] # [[Gros Islet Quarter|Gros Islet]] # [[Laborie Quarter|Laborie]] # [[Micoud Quarter|Micoud]] # [[SoufriÃ¨re Quarter|SoufriÃ¨re]] # [[Vieux Fort Quarter|Vieux Fort]] ==Natural hazards== [[Hurricane]]s and volcanic activity. The island was severely affected by [[Hurricane Allen]] in 1980 and [[Hurricane Tomas]] in 2010, causing agricultural damage and a drop in visitor arrivals, but Saint Lucia has generally had fewer hurricanes than many other Caribbean islands, due to its southerly location. Hurricanes and volcanoes would both damage the coral. ==Environment== ===Current issues=== Deforestation; soil erosion, particularly in the northern region. ===International agreements=== ''party to:'' [[Biodiversity]], [[United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change|Climate Change]], [[Desertification]], [[Endangered Species]], [[Environmental Modification]], [[Hazardous Wastes]], [[Law of the Sea]], [[Marine Dumping]], [[Ozone Layer Protection]], [[Whaling]], [[Climate Change-Kyoto Protocol]] ==See also== * [[List of rivers of Saint Lucia]] * [[Demographics of Saint Lucia]] ==References== {{commons category|Geography of Saint Lucia}} * {{loc}} * {{cite book | author=Philpott, Don | title=St Lucia | location=Derbyshire | publisher=Landmark Publishing Ltd | year=1999 | isbn=1-901522-28-8 }} * {{cite book | author=Higgins, Chris | title=St. Lucia | location=Montreal | publisher=Ulysses Travel Guides| year=2001 | isbn=2-89464-396-9}} {{Geography of North America}} {{North America topic|Climate of}} [[Category:Geography of Saint Lucia| ]]

'''Industrial Nature''' is the regeneration of natural vegetation on industrial sites; the invasion of abandoned or disused industrial sites by colonising species; or new plantings on abandoned, disused or remediated industrial sites. The underlying principal is that the historical industrial use of landscapes or sites creates a new environment which species can use either by design as in the case of a park or revegetated area, or by colonisation.
The concept has its origins in Germany, specifically at the [[Emscher Landscape Park]] in the Ruhr, (of which the [[Landschaftspark Duisburg-Nord]] is the best known example) and has been applied at the Sudgelande Park in Berlin.
Another example can be found at the Deutsches Technikmuseum [[German Museum of Technology (Berlin)]], at the former locomotive workshops and goods yard (Anhalter GÃ¼terbahnhof) of Berlin-Anhalt Railway Company. Here much of the goods yards and part of the roundhouse complex has been left as a ruin, colonised by a variety of non-native plants.

{{Infobox park | name = Jardin Exotique de Monaco | alt_name = | photo = Monaco002.jpg | photo_width = 256 | photo_caption = View on Monte Carlo as seen from the Exotic garden | type = [[Botanical garden]] | location = | map = | map_label =Jardin Exotique de Monaco | map_width = 208 | coords = {{coord|43|43|56|N|7|24|50|E|display=title, inline|region:MC_type:landmark_source:dewiki}} | area = | opened = | operator = | visitation_num = | status = | website = https://web.archive.org/web/20050508162801/http://www.jardin-exotique.mc/accueil_eng.htm }} The '''Jardin Exotique de Monaco''' ([[French language|French]] for "exotic garden of Monaco") is a [[botanical garden]] located on a cliffside in [[Monaco]].
==History== The [[succulent plant]]s were brought back from [[Mexico]] in the late 1860s.<ref name=jardinexot>{{cite journal|last1=Cohen|first1=Paul|first2=Cohen|last2=Brenda|title=Le Jardin Exotique, Les Grottes de L'Observatoire, and Le MusÃ©e D'Anthropolgie PrÃ©historique in Monaco |journal=Journal of College Science Teaching |date=December 1998 |volume=28|issue=3|pages=208â209|jstor=42990109|registration=yes}}</ref> By 1895, [[Augustin Gastaud]], who served as the Chief Gardener of the State Gardens of Monaco, grew the succulents in the Jardin St Martin.<ref name=jardinexot/><ref name=nice75ans>{{cite news|last1=Arama|first1=GaÃ«lle|title=Monaco Jardin exotique : 75 ans et toujours autant de piquant ?|url=http://archives.nicematin.com/article/environnement/monaco-jardin-exotique-75-ans-et-toujours-autant-de-piquant.51072.html|accessdate=December 24, 2015|work=Nice Matin|date=June 8, 2008}}</ref>
[[Albert I, Prince of Monaco]] acquired a piece of land in [[Les Moneghetti]] in 1912.<ref name=jardinexot/> He commissioned [[Louis Notari]], the Chief Engineer of Monaco, to build a new garden with [[footbridge]]s.<ref name=jardinexot/> During the construction, Notari found a [[grotto]] underneath in 1916.<ref name=jardinexot/> Meanwhile, the garden was dedicated in 1933.<ref name=jardinexot/> Monegasque agronomist [[Louis Vatrican]] served as its first director from 1933 to 1969.<ref name=nice75ans/> He added African succulents to the existing South African plants.<ref name=nice75ans/> After he retired in 1969, he was succeeded by [[Marcel Kroenlein]].<ref name=nice75ans/>
The grotto was opened to the public in 1950, but it may only be visited with specialized guides. Evidence of prehistoric human inhabitants has been found in the cave.<ref name=jardinexot/> There is a [[museum of Prehistoric Anthropology]] within the Exotic Garden displaying many of those prehistoric remains.<ref name=jardinexot/> It was founded by Prince Albert I in 1902.

{{Good Article}} {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2012}} {{Infobox lake |name = Lake Vostok |image = Lake Vostok Sat Photo color.jpg |caption = Radar satellite image of Lake Vostok |image_bathymetry = |caption_bathymetry = |coords = {{coord|77|30|S|106|00|E|type:waterbody_region:AQ_scale:4000000|display=inline,title}} |lake_type = [[subglacial lake|Subglacial]] [[rift lake]] |inflow = |outflow = |catchment = |basin_countries = [[Antarctica]] |length = {{Convert|250|km|mi|-1|abbr=on}}<ref name='ASOC'/> |width = {{Convert|50|km|mi|-1|abbr=on}}<ref name='ASOC'/> |area = {{Convert|12500|km2|mi2|-1|abbr=on}} |depth = {{Convert|432|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} |max-depth = {{Convert|510|m|ft|-2|abbr=on}}<ref name='ASOC'/> to {{Convert|900|m|ft|-2|abbr=on}}<ref name=facts/> |volume = {{Convert|5400|km3|mi3|-2|abbr=on}}<ref name=facts/> Â± {{Convert|1600|km3|mi3|-2|abbr=on}} |residence_time = 13,300 yrs |shore = |elevation = c. {{Convert|-500|m|ft|-2|abbr=on}} |islands = 1 |cities = [[Vostok Station]]}} '''Lake Vostok''' ({{lang-ru|ÐÐ·ÐµÑÐ¾ ÐÐ¾ÑÑÐ¾Ðº}}, ''Ozero Vostok'', lit. "Lake East") is the largest of [[Antarctica]]'s almost 400 known [[subglacial lake]]s. Lake Vostok is located at the southern [[Pole of Cold]], beneath Russia's [[Vostok Station]] under the surface of the central [[East Antarctic Ice Sheet]], which is at {{Convert|3488|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} [[sea level|above mean sea level]]. The surface of this [[fresh water]] lake is approximately {{Convert|4000|m|ft|-2|abbr=on}} under the surface of the ice, which places it at approximately {{Convert|500|m|ft|-2|abbr=on}} below sea level.
Measuring {{Convert|250|km|mi|-1|abbr=on}} long by {{Convert|50|km|mi|-1|abbr=on}} wide at its widest point<ref name="ASOC" />, it covers an area of {{Convert|12500|km2|sqmi|-1|abbr=on}} making it the [[List of lakes by area|16th largest lake by surface area]]. With an average depth of {{Convert|432|m|ft|0|abbr=on}}, it has an estimated volume of {{Convert|5400|km3|mi3|-2|abbr=on}}.<ref name="facts">{{cite web |url=http://www.ldeo.columbia.edu/~mstuding/facts_about_lakes.html |title=Subglacial Lake Facts |publisher=Ldeo.columbia.edu |date= |accessdate=7 February 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120102111109/http://www.ldeo.columbia.edu/~mstuding/facts_about_lakes.html |archivedate=2 January 2012 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> making it the [[List of lakes by volume|6th largest lake by volume]].
The lake is divided into two deep [[Endorheic basin|basins]] by a ridge. The liquid water depth over the ridge is about {{Convert|200|m|ft|-2|abbr=on}}, compared to roughly {{Convert|400|m|ft|-2|abbr=on}} deep in the northern basin and {{Convert|800|m|ft|-2|abbr=on}} deep in the southern.
The lake is named after Vostok Station, which in turn is named after the ''[[Vostok (sloop-of-war)|Vostok]]'' (ÐÐ¾ÑÑÐ¾Ðº), a [[sloop-of-war]] ship, which means "East" in Russian.<ref name="vostokcoin">{{cite book |title=Watercraft on World Coins: Europe, 1800-2005 |publisher=The Alpha Press |last=Dotan |first=Yossi |date=2007 |pages=220 |isbn=978-1-898595-49-6 |quote=The 900-ton Vostok was built in 1818 at the Okhta Shipyard of Stoke and Kolodnin in St. Petersburg. }}</ref> The existence of a subglacial lake in the Vostok region was first suggested by Russian geographer [[Andrey Kapitsa]] based on seismic soundings made during the [[Soviet Antarctic Expedition]]s in 1959 and 1964 to measure the thickness of the ice sheet.<ref name=appeal/><ref name=lenta-kapitsa/> The continued research by Russian and British scientists<ref name=lenta-kapitsa/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://newsru.com/russia/03aug2011/kapica.html |title=Ð£Ð¼ÐµÑ ÑÑÐµÐ½ÑÐ¹ ÐÐ½Ð´ÑÐµÐ¹ ÐÐ°Ð¿Ð¸ÑÐ°, ÑÐ´ÐµÐ»Ð°Ð²ÑÐ¸Ð¹ Ð² ÐÐ½ÑÐ°ÑÐºÑÐ¸Ð´Ðµ Ð¾Ð´Ð½Ð¾ Ð¸Ð· ÐºÑÑÐ¿Ð½ÐµÐ¹ÑÐ¸Ñ Ð¾ÑÐºÑÑÑÐ¸Ð¹ XX Ð²ÐµÐºÐ° |language=Russian |trans-title=The author of one of the greatest discoveries, Andrey Kapitsa, died |publisher=NEWSru.com |date=3 August 2011 |accessdate=25 August 2012 }}</ref> led by 1993 to the final confirmation of the existence of the lake by J. P. Ridley using [[European Remote-Sensing Satellite|ERS-1]] laser altimetry.<ref name=appeal/>
The overlying ice provides a continuous [[Paleoclimatology|paleoclimatic record]] of 400,000 years, although the lake water itself may have been isolated for 15<ref name="January 2011">{{cite news |first=K |last=Moskvitch |title=Lake Vostok drilling in Antarctic 'running out of time' |date=27 January 2011 |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-12275979 |work=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=28 January 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Casey Kazan |title=Secrets of Antarctica's 15-Million Year-Old Lake -A Galaxy Classic |date=5 December 2007 |url=http://www.dailygalaxy.com/my_weblog/2007/12/secret-life-o-1.html |work=The Daily Galaxy |accessdate=20 August 2012 }}</ref> to 25 million years.<ref name="Studinger">{{cite web |url=http://www.ldeo.columbia.edu/~mstuding/vostok.html |title=Subglacial Lake Vostok |first=M |last=Studinger |date=2008 |publisher=Columbia University |accessdate=1 February 2011 }}</ref> On 5 February 2012, a team of Russian scientists completed the longest ever [[ice core]] of {{Convert |3768 |m |ft |-2 |abbr=on}} and pierced the ice shield to the surface of the lake.<ref name=Kaufman>{{cite news |author=Marc Kaufman |title=Russians drill into previously untouched Lake Vostok below Antarctic glacier |date=6 February 2012 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/health-science/russians-drill-into-previously-untouched-lake-vostok-below-antarctica/2012/02/06/gIQAGziNuQ_story.html |work=The Washington Post |accessdate=6 February 2012 }}</ref>
The first core of freshly frozen lake ice was obtained on 10 January 2013 at a depth of {{convert|3406|m|ft|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite news |author=Amir Khan |title=Buried Lake Reached: Lake Vostok Water Retrieved After 14 Million Years |date=15 January 2013 |url=http://www.isciencetimes.com/articles/4375/20130115/buried-lake-reached-vostok-water-retrieved-14-million-years.htm |work=International Science Times |accessdate=22 January 2013 }}</ref><ref name=ID>{{cite news |title=Russian scientists discover unidentified bacteria in sub-glacial Lake Vostok |date=7 March 2013 |url=http://rt.com/news/lake-vostok-russia-bacteria-944/ |work=Russia Today |accessdate=7 March 2013 }}</ref> However, as soon as the ice was pierced, water from the underlying lake gushed up the [[borehole]], mixing it with the [[Freon]] and [[kerosene]] used to keep the borehole from freezing.<ref>{{cite news |author=Douglas Fox |title=Hidden Antarctic Lake Spills Its Secrets |date=February 2013 |url=http://discovermagazine.com/2013/jan-feb/35-hidden-antarctic-lake-spills-its-secrets |work=Discover Magazine |accessdate=22 January 2013 }}</ref><ref name="New bore 2015">{{cite news |url=http://on.rt.com/awrk2m |title=Lake Vostok breakthrough: Russian scientists drill âcleanâ hole into Antarctic subglacial basin |work=Russia Today (RT) |location=Russia |date=January 25, 2015 |accessdate=2015-01-25 }}</ref><ref name="Lagnado"/><ref name="DNA analyses"/> A new borehole was drilled and an allegedly pristine water sample was obtained in January 2015.<ref name="New bore 2015"/> The Russian team plans to eventually lower a probe into the lake to collect water samples and sediments from the bottom. It is hypothesized that unusual forms of life could be found in the lake's liquid layer, a [[fossil water]] reserve. Because Lake Vostok may contain an environment sealed off below the ice for millions of years, the conditions could resemble those of ice-covered oceans hypothesized to exist on [[Jupiter]]'s moon [[Europa (moon)|Europa]],<ref name="lost world">{{cite news |title='Lost World' reached: 20 million yr old Antarctic lake 'drilled' |date=6 February 2012 |url=http://rt.com/news/antarctic-million-secrets-lake-583/ |work=RT |accessdate=20 August 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Rob Cooper |title=Triumph! |date=9 February 2012 |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2095193/Lake-Vostok-Russian-scientists-confirm-triumph-drilling-successful-Antarctica.html |work=Mail Online |accessdate=20 August 2012 }}</ref> and [[Saturn]]'s moon [[Enceladus]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.dailygalaxy.com/my_weblog/2014/07/the-geysers-of-enceladus-will-saturns-moon-reveal-a-second-genesis.html |title=The Geysers of Enceladus - Will Saturn's Moon Reveal a "Second Genesis"? |work=The Daily Galaxy |date=31 July 2014 |accessdate=2015-10-27 }}</ref>
==Discovery== [[File:LakeVostok-Location.jpg|thumb |left |Location of Lake Vostok in [[East Antarctica]]]] Russian scientist [[Peter Kropotkin]] first proposed the idea of fresh water under Antarctic [[ice sheet]]s at the end of the 19th century.<ref>"Research on the [[Ice age]]", ''Notices of the Imperial Russian Geographical Society'', 1876.</ref> He theorized that the tremendous pressure exerted by the cumulative mass of thousands of vertical meters of ice could increase the temperature at the lowest portions of the ice sheet to the [[Pressure melting point|point where the ice would melt]]. Kropotkin's theory was further developed by Russian [[glaciology|glaciologist]] I. A. Zotikov, who wrote his [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] thesis on this subject in 1967.<ref name=appeal/>
Russian geographer [[Andrey Kapitsa]] used seismic soundings in the region of [[Vostok Station]] made during the [[Soviet Antarctic Expedition]] in 1959 and 1964 to measure the thickness of the ice sheet.<ref name=appeal>{{cite web |url=http://www.asoc.org/storage/documents/Other_publications/asoc_vostok_statement041408.pdf |format=PDF |title=Appeal to the Duma on Lake Vostok, Antarctica |date=14 April 2008 |work=Antarctic and Southern Ocean Coalition |accessdate=10 February 2011 }}</ref> Kapitsa was the first to suggest the existence of a subglacial lake in the region,<ref name=lenta-kapitsa>{{cite web |url=http://lenta.ru/news/2011/08/03/kapitsa/ |script-title=ru:Ð¡ÐºÐ¾Ð½ÑÐ°Ð»ÑÑ Ð¿ÐµÑÐ²Ð¾Ð¾ÑÐºÑÑÐ²Ð°ÑÐµÐ»Ñ Ð¾Ð·ÐµÑÐ° ÐÐ¾ÑÑÐ¾Ðº Ð² ÐÐ½ÑÐ°ÑÐºÑÐ¸Ð´Ðµ |trans-title=Discoverer of the Lake Vostok in the Antarctica died |publisher=[[Lenta.ru]] |language=Russian |date=3 March 2011 }}</ref> and the subsequent research confirmed his hypothesis.<ref name=rgs>{{cite news |title=Andrey Kapitsa dies in Moscow |url=http://int.rgo.ru/news/andrey-kapitsa-dies-in-moscow/ |work=[[Russian Geographical Society]] |quote=In cooperation with other scientists, Andrey Kapitsa made one of the most remarkable geographical discoveries of the 20th century â a vast lake beneath the Antarctic ice, near the polar research station Vostok. |date=3 August 2011 |accessdate=4 August 2011 }}</ref>
When British scientists in Antarctica performed airborne ice-penetrating [[radar]] surveys in the early 1970s, they detected unusual radar readings at the site which suggested the presence of a liquid freshwater lake below the ice.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Oswald |first=GKA |last2=Robin |first2=G. de Q. |date=1973 |title=Lakes beneath the Antarctic Ice Sheet |journal=Nature |volume=245 |issue=5423 |pages=251â4 |doi=10.1038/245251a0 |url= |bibcode=1973Natur.245..251O }}</ref> In 1991, Jeff Ridley, a [[remote sensing]] specialist with the [[Mullard Space Science Laboratory]] at [[University College London]], directed the [[European Remote-Sensing Satellite|ERS-1]] satellite to turn its high-frequency array toward the center of the Antarctic [[ice cap]]. The data from ERS-1 confirmed the findings from the 1973 British surveys,<ref name=Morton>{{cite web |url=https://www.wired.com/wired/archive/8.04/vostok_pr.html |title=Ice Station Vostok |first=O |last=Morton |publisher=Wired |accessdate=31 January 2011 }}</ref> but these new data were not published in the ''[[Journal of Glaciology]]'' until 1993. [[Space-based radar]] revealed that this subglacial body of fresh water is one of the largest lakes in the world, and one of some 140 subglacial lakes in Antarctica. Russian and British scientists delineated the lake in 1996 by integrating a variety of data, including airborne ice-penetrating [[radar imaging]] observations and space-based radar altimetry. It has been confirmed that the lake contains large amounts of liquid water under the more than {{convert|3|km|mi|sp=us|adj=mid|-thick}} ice cap. The lake has at least 22 [[Glacier cave|cavities of liquid water]], averaging {{convert|10|km|mi|sp=us|0}} each.<ref name="FÃ¼ttererKleinschmidt2006">{{cite book |first=Dieter |last=FÃ¼tterer |first2=Georg |last2=Kleinschmidt |title=Antarctica: contributions to global Earth sciences: proceedings of the IX International Symposium of Antarctic Earth Sciences Potsdam, 2003 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PcJcEvPFpT4C&pg=PA138 |date=2006 |publisher=BirkhÃ¤user |isbn=978-3-540-30673-3 |page=138 |accessdate=15 May 2011 }}</ref>
The station after which the lake is named commemorates the ''[[Vostok (sloop-of-war)|Vostok]]'' (ÐÐ¾ÑÑÐ¾Ðº), the 900-ton [[sloop-of-war]] ship sailed by one of the discoverers of Antarctica, [[Russian explorers|Russian explorer]] Admiral [[Fabian Gottlieb von Bellingshausen|Fabian von Bellingshausen]].<ref name="vostokcoin" /> Because the word ''Vostok'' means "East" in Russian, the names of the station and lake also reflect the fact that they are located in East Antarctica.
In 2005 an island was found in the central part of the lake.<ref name=island>{{cite news |first=D |last=Whitehouse |title=Russia to resume Vostok drilling |date=25 May 2005 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/4577627.stm |work=BBC News |accessdate=28 January 2011 }}</ref> Then, in January 2006, the discovery of two nearby smaller lakes under the ice cap was published; they are named [[90 Degrees East]] and [[Sovetskaya (lake)|Sovetskaya]].<ref>Robin Bell and Michael Studinger, [[Geophysical]] researchers from [[Columbia University]], published in ''[[Geophysical Research Letters]]''</ref> It is suspected that these Antarctic subglacial lakes may be connected by a network of subglacial rivers. [[Centre for Polar Observation & Modelling]] glaciologists propose that many of the subglacial lakes of Antarctica are at least temporarily interconnected.<ref name="Siegert"/> Because of varying water pressure in individual lakes, large subsurface rivers may suddenly form and then force large amounts of water through the solid ice.<ref name="Siegert"/>
==Geological history== {{further information |Geology of Antarctica |Gondwana}} Africa separated from Antarctica around 160 million years ago, followed by the [[Indian subcontinent]], in the early [[Cretaceous]] (about 125 million years ago). About 66 million years ago, Antarctica (then connected to Australia) still had a [[tropics|tropical]] to [[subtropics|subtropical]] climate, complete with [[marsupial]] [[fauna]] and an extensive [[temperate rainforest]].<ref>{{cite news|first=L |last=O'Hanl |title=Antarctic Forests Reveal Ancient Trees |date=5 November 2004 |url=http://dsc.discovery.com/news/briefs/20041101/leaves.html?ct=6817.32046957226 |work=Discovery News |accessdate=31 January 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110628230903/http://dsc.discovery.com/news/briefs/20041101/leaves.html?ct=6817.32046957226 |archivedate=28 June 2011 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Frozen in time: Fossils from the Antarctic |date=2012 |url=http://www.antarctica.ac.uk/about_antarctica/geography/rock/fossil-collection.php |work=[[British Antarctic Survey]] |accessdate=20 August 2012 }}</ref>
The Lake Vostok basin is a small ({{convert|50|km|mi|sp=us|adj=mid|-wide}}) [[Tectonics|tectonic]] feature within the overall setting of a several-hundred-kilometer-wide [[continental collision]] zone between the [[Gamburtsev Mountain Range]], a subglacial [[mountain range]] and the [[Dome C]] region.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ldeo.columbia.edu/~mstuding/tectonic_control.html |title=Tectonic Control of Subglacial Lakes |author=Michael Studinger |date=2006 |work=Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory |publisher=LamonâDoherty Earth Observatory, [[Columbia University]] |accessdate=20 August 2012 }}</ref> The lake water is cradled on a bed of [[Glaciolacustrine deposits|sediments]] {{convert|70|m|ft|sp=us}} thick, offering the possibility that they contain a unique record of the climate and life in Antarctica before the ice cap formed.<ref name=Morton/><ref>{{cite news |author=Robert Lee Hotz |title=Miles Below Antarctic Ice, a Freshwater Lake May Harbor Ancient Life |date=3 March 2001 |url=http://www.earthinstitute.columbia.edu/news/story3_2_01a.html |work=The Los Angeles Times |accessdate=20 August 2012 }}</ref>
==Traits== [[File:Wostok-Station core32.jpg|thumb |[[Vostok Station]]]] The lake water is estimated to have been sealed off under the thick ice sheet about 15 million years ago.<ref name="January 2011" /> Initially, it was thought that the same water had made up the lake since the time of its formation, giving a [[Residence time (fluid dynamics)|residence time]] in the order of one million years.<ref name="Siegert"/> Later research by [[Robin Bell (scientist)|Robin Bell]] and Michael Studinger from the [[LamontâDoherty Earth Observatory]] of [[Columbia University]] suggested that the water of the lake is continually freezing and being carried away by the motion of the [[Antarctic ice sheet]], while being replaced by water melting from other parts of the ice sheet in these high pressure conditions. This resulted in an estimate that the entire volume of the lake is replaced every 13,300 years — its effective mean residence time.<ref name="bell_2003">{{cite web |url=http://www.earthinstitute.columbia.edu/news/2003/story08-27-03.html |publisher=[[The Earth Institute]] at [[Columbia University]] |title=Columbia University Scientists Present Long Sought Opportunities to Safely Explore Life Within Earth's Most Ancient and Inaccessible Ecosystem |date=21 March 2002 |accessdate=31 March 2010 }}</ref>
The coldest naturally occurring temperature ever observed on Earth, {{convert|-89|Â°C|Â°F|0|abbr=on|lk=on}}, was recorded at Vostok Station on 21 July 1983.<ref name="January 2011" /> The average water temperature is calculated to be around {{convert|-3|Â°C|Â°F|0|abbr=on}}; it remains liquid below the normal [[melting point|freezing point]] because of high pressure from the weight of the ice above it.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.Lakelubbers.com/lake-vostok-978/ |title=Lake Vostok, Antarctica |date=2012 |publisher=Lakelubbers LLC |accessdate=6 February 2012 }}</ref> [[Geothermal gradient|Geothermal]] heat from the Earth's interior may warm the bottom of the lake,<ref name="vincent">{{cite book |first=Warwick F. |last=Vincent |first2=Johanna |last2=Laybourn-Parry |title=Polar lakes and rivers: limnology of Arctic and Antarctic aquatic ecosystems |work=Oxford University Press |page=129 |url=https://www.google.com/search?source=ig&hl=en&rlz=&=&q=lake+vostok+temperature+pressure&oq=lake+vostok+temperature+pressure&aq=f&aqi=&aql=&gs_sm=3&gs_upl=636l9329l0l9526l32l26l0l14l14l0l746l1840l2-4.6-1l5l0#pq=lake+vostok+temperature+pressure&hl=en&sugexp=cpsu2&tok=BBZrvHhz4EdZnmEteRvcjw&cp=29&gs_id=2q&xhr=t&q=lake+vostok+oxygen+geothermal&pf=p&sclient=psy-ab&source=hp&pbx=1&oq=lake+vostok+oxygen+geothermal&aq=f&aqi=&aql=&gs_sm=&gs_upl=&bav=on.2,or.r_gc.r_pw.,cf.osb&fp=ec6c5a228a807607&biw=1097&bih=472 |accessdate=6 February 2012 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sale.scar.org/key-programs/limnology-the-long-version.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121203051651/http://www.sale.scar.org/key-programs/limnology-the-long-version.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=3 December 2012 |title=Subglacial Lake Environments |accessdate=6 February 2012}} </ref><ref>{{cite book |first=IgorÊ¹ Alekseevich |last=Zotikov |title=The Antarctic subglacial Lake Vostok: glaciology, biology and planetology |publisher=Springer Praxis Books / Geophysical Sciences |date=26 July 2006 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=imR2nsVPTWcC&pg=PA85&lpg=PA85&dq=lake+vostok+oxygen+geothermal#v=onepage&q&f=false |isbn=978-3-540-42649-3 |accessdate=6 February 2012 }}</ref> while the ice sheet itself insulates the lake from cold temperatures on the surface.
Lake Vostok is an [[oligotroph]]ic extreme environment, one that is expected to be [[Supersaturation|supersaturated]] with nitrogen and oxygen,<ref>{{cite journal |title=Insights into hydrological regime of Lake Vostok from differential behavior of deuterium and oxygen-18 in accreted ice |journal=Journal of Geophysical Research |date=2010 |first=AA |display-authors=4 |last=Ekaykin |first2=VY |last2=Lipenkov |first3=JR |last3=Petit |first4=S |last4=Johnsen |first5=J |last5=Jouzel |first6=V |last6=Masson-Delmotte |volume=115 |issue=C05003 |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/2009JC005329/full|accessdate=28 January 2011 |doi=10.1029/2009JC005329 |bibcode=2010JGRC..115.5003E}}</ref><ref name="Bulat">{{cite journal |title=Searching for life in extreme environments relevant to Jovian's Europa: Lessons from subglacial ice studies at Lake Vostok (East Antarctica) |journal=Advances in Space Research |date=2010 |first=SA |display-authors=4 |last=Bulat |first2=Irina A. |last2=Alekhina |first3=Dominique |last3=Marie |first4=Jean |last4=Martins |first5=Jean Robert |last5=Petit |doi=10.1016/j.asr.2010.11.024 |bibcode=2011AdSpR..48..697B |volume=48 |issue=4 |pages=697â701 }}</ref> measuring {{convert|2.5|l|cuft}} of nitrogen and oxygen per {{convert|1|kg|lb|abbr=on}} of water,<ref name="Burton">{{cite news |first=K |last=Burton |title=Researchers find antarctic lake water will fizz like a soda |date=11 August 2003 |url=http://www.nasa.gov/centers/ames/news/releases/2003/03_57AR.html |work=NASA |accessdate=28 January 2011 }}</ref> that is 50 times higher than those typically found in ordinary freshwater lakes on Earth's surface. The sheer weight and pressure around {{convert|345|bar|psi|lk=on}} of the continental ice cap on top of Lake Vostok is estimated to contribute to the high gas concentration.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Physical, chemical and biological processes in Lake Vostok and other Antarctic subglacial lakes |journal=Nature |first=MJ |display-authors=4 |last=Siegert |first2=J. Cynan |last2=Ellis-Evans |first3=Martyn |last3=Tranter |first4=Christoph |last4=Mayer |first5=Jean-Robert |last5=Petit |first6=Andrey |last6=Salamatin |first7=John C. |last7=Priscu |volume=414 |pages=603â9 |url=http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v414/n6864/abs/414603a.html |doi=10.1038/414603a |date=2001 |issue=6864 |pmid=11740551 }}</ref>
Besides dissolving in the water, oxygen and other gases are trapped in a type of structure called a [[Clathrate hydrate|clathrate]]. In clathrate structures, gases are enclosed in an icy cage and look like packed snow. These structures form at the high-pressure depths of Lake Vostok and would become unstable if brought to the surface.<ref name="Siegert">{{cite journal |last=Siegert |first=MJ |title=The identification, examination and exploration of Antarctic subglacial lakes |journal=Sci Prog |volume=83 |issue=3 |pages=223â42 |date=2000 |pmid=11077478 |doi= }}</ref><ref name="Burton" />
In April 2005, German, Russian, and Japanese researchers found that the lake has [[tide]]s.<ref>{{cite journal |title=The response of the subglacial Lake Vostok, Antarctica, to tidal and atmospheric pressure forcing |journal=[[Geophysical Journal International]] |first=A |display-authors=4 |last=Wendt |first2=Reinhard |last2=Dietrich |first3=Jens |last3=Wendt |first4=Mathias |last4=Fritsche |first5=Valery |last5=Lukin |first6=Alexander |last6=Yuskevich |first7=Andrey |last7=Kokhanov |first8=Anton |last8=Senatorov |first9=Kazuo |last9=Shibuya |first10=Koichiro |last10=Doi |volume=161 |issue=1 |pages=41â9 |doi=10.1111/j.1365-246X.2005.02575.x |date=2005 |bibcode=2005GeoJI.161...41W }}</ref> Depending on the position of the Sun and the Moon, the surface of the lake rises about {{convert|12|mm|in|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Evidence for tides in the subglacial Lake Vostok, Antarctica |journal=Geophysical Research Letters |date=2001 |first=R |last=Dietrich |first2=K. |last2=Shibuya |first3=A. |last3=PÃ¶tzsch |first4=T. |last4=Ozawa |volume=28 |issue=15 |pages=2971â4 |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1029/2001GL013230/pdf |doi=10.1029/2001GL013230 |bibcode=2001GeoRL..28.2971D |accessdate=4 February 2011 }}</ref> The lake is under complete darkness, under {{convert|355|bar|psi|abbr=on}} of pressure, and expected to be rich in oxygen, so there is speculation that any organisms inhabiting the lake could have evolved in a manner unique to this environment.<ref name=Morton/><ref name="Burton" /> There is a 1 [[Tesla (unit)|microtesla]] [[magnetic anomaly]] on the east coast of the lake, spanning {{Convert |105 |by |75 |km |mi |abbr=on}}. Researchers hypothesize that the anomaly may be caused by a thinning of the Earth's crust in that location.<ref>{{cite news |title=SOARing Below Vostok |first=Kristan Hutchinson |last=Sabbatini |url=http://antarcticsun.usap.gov/pastIssues/2000-2001/2001_02_04.pdf |format=PDF |newspaper=The Antarctic Sun |date=4 February 2001 |accessdate=3 February 2012 }}</ref>
Living ''[[Hydrogenophilaceae|Hydrogenophilus thermoluteolus]]'' micro-organisms have been found in Lake Vostok's deep ice core drillings; they are an [[Extant taxon|extant]] surface-dwelling species.<ref name="Bulat" /><ref name="Bull2004">{{cite book |first=Alan T. |last=Bull |title=Microbial diversity and bioprospecting |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cDeuY0ON6RQC&pg=PA139 |date=2004 |publisher=ASM Press |isbn=978-1-55581-267-6 |pages=139â |accessdate=15 May 2011 }}</ref> This suggests the presence of a deep [[biosphere]] utilizing a geothermal system of the bedrock encircling the subglacial lake. There is optimism that microbial life in the lake may be possible despite high pressure, constant cold, low nutrient input, potentially high oxygen concentration and an absence of sunlight.<ref name="Bulat" /><ref>{{cite journal |title=DNA signature of thermophilic bacteria from the aged accretion ice of Lake Vostok, Antarctica: implications for searching for life in extreme icy environments |journal=[[International Journal of Astrobiology]] |date=August 2004 |first=SA |display-authors=4 |last=Bulat |first2=Irina A. |last2=Alekhina |first3=Michel |last3=Blot |first4=Jean-Robert |last4=Petit |first5=Martine |last5=de Angelis |first6=Dietmar |last6=Wagenbach |first7=Vladimir Ya. |last7=Lipenkov |first8=Lada P. |last8=Vasilyeva |first9=Dominika M. |last9=Wloch |first10=Dominique |last10=Raynaud |first11=Valery V. |last11=Lukin |volume=3 |pages=1â12 |url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=240767 |doi=10.1017/S1473550404001879 |bibcode=2004IJAsB...3....1B |accessdate=29 January 2011 }}</ref><ref>"...microbes found in accreted ice of Lake Vostok were relatively modern, but the probability of ancient lake-floor sediments led to a possibility of a very old biota at the base of subglacial lakes." {{cite journal |title=Biological and Morphological Studies Carried out in Antarctic Lakes |journal=International Journal of Lakes and Rivers |date=2009 |first=N |last=Khare |first2=Abhijit |last2=Mazumder |first3=Rajni |last3=Srivastava |first4=Ashwani |last4=Wangneo |volume=2 |issue=1 |pages=57â102 |url=http://www.ripublication.com/ijlr/ijlrv2n1_7.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110110100127/http://www.ripublication.com/ijlr/ijlrv2n1_7.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-01-10 |format=PDF |accessdate=4 February 2011 }}</ref> [[Jupiter]]'s moon [[Europa (moon)|Europa]] and [[Saturn]]'s moon [[Enceladus (moon)|Enceladus]] may also harbor lakes or oceans below a thick crust of ice. Any confirmation of life in Lake Vostok could strengthen the prospect for the presence of life on icy moons.<ref name="Bulat" /><ref name="tdg">{{cite web |url=http://www.dailygalaxy.com/my_weblog/2007/12/secret-life-o-1.html |title=Mystery of Antarctica's 15-Million Year-Old Lake |date=4 December 2007 |work=The Daily Galaxy |accessdate=5 December 2007 }}</ref>
==Research== [[File:GISP2 team photo core37.jpeg|thumb |[[Ice core]]s drilled at Vostok Station, which is seen in the background]] Researchers working at Vostok Station produced one of the world's longest [[ice core]]s in 1998. A joint Russian, French, and United States team drilled and analyzed the core, which is {{convert|3623|m|ft|abbr=on}} long. Ice samples from cores drilled close to the top of the lake have been assessed to be as old as 420,000 years. The assumption is that the lake has been sealed from the surface since the ice sheet formed, 15 million years ago. Drilling of the core was deliberately halted roughly {{convert |100|m|ft|sigfig=1|abbr=on}}<ref name="Jouzel">{{cite journal |display-authors=4 |last=Jouzel |first=J |last2=Petit |first2=JR |last3=Souchez |first3=R |last4=Barkov |first4=NI |last5=Lipenkov |first5=VY |last6=Raynaud |first6=D |last7=Stievenard |first7=M |last8=Vassiliev |first8=NI |last9=Verbeke |first9=V |last10=Vimeux |first10=F |title=More than 200 meters of lake ice above subglacial Lake Vostok, Antarctica |journal=Science |volume=286 |issue=5447 |pages=2138â41 |date=1999 |pmid=10591641 |doi=10.1126/science.286.5447.2138 }}</ref> above the suspected boundary between the ice sheet and the liquid waters of the lake. This was to prevent contamination of the lake with the 60-ton column of [[Chlorofluorocarbon|Freon]] and [[kerosene]] used to prevent the borehole from collapsing and freezing over.<ref name=Morton/>
From this core, specifically from ice that is thought to have formed from lake water freezing onto the base of the ice sheet, [[extremophile|extremophile microbes]] were found, suggesting that the lake water supports life. Scientists suggested that the lake could possess a unique habitat for ancient [[bacteria]] with an isolated microbial [[gene pool]] containing characteristics developed perhaps 500,000 years ago.<ref>{{cite journal |display-authors=4 |last=Priscu |first=JC |last2=Adams |first2=EE |last3=Lyons |first3=WB |last4=Voytek |first4=MA |last5=Mogk |first5=DW |last6=Brown |first6=RL |last7=McKay |first7=CP |last8=Takacs |first8=CD |last9=Welch |first9=KA |last10=Wolf |first10=CF |last11=Kirshtein |first11=JD |last12=Avci |first12=R |title=Geomicrobiology of subglacial ice above Lake Vostok, Antarctica |journal=Science |volume=286 |issue=5447 |pages=2141â4 |date=1999 |pmid=10591642 |doi=10.1126/science.286.5447.2141 }}</ref>
[[File:Lake Vostok drill 2011.jpg|thumb|left |An artist's cross-section of Lake Vostok's drilling]] In January 2011, the head of the Russian Antarctic Expedition, Valery Lukin, announced that his team had only {{Convert |50 |m |ft |-2 |abbr=on}} of ice left to drill in order to reach the water.<ref name="January 2011" /> The researchers then switched to a new thermal drill head with a "clean" [[silicone oil]] fluid to drill the rest of the way.<ref>{{cite news |first=L |last=Edwards |title=Russians hope to reach Lake Vostok for the first time soon |date=10 January 2011 |url=http://www.physorg.com/news/2011-01-russians-lake-vostok.html |work=Physorg |accessdate=29 January 2011 }}</ref> Instead of drilling all the way into the water, they said they would stop just above it when a sensor on the thermal drill detected free water. At that point, the drill was to be stopped and extracted from the bore hole. Removal of the drill would lower the pressure beneath it, drawing water into the hole to be left to freeze, creating a plug of ice in the bottom of the hole.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Vasiliev |first=N. I. |last2=Talalay |first2=Pavel G. |title=Twenty years of drilling the deepest hole in ice |journal=Scientific Drilling |volume=11 |pages=41â45 |doi=10.2204/iodp.sd.11.05.2011 |date=2011 |issue=11, March 2011 }}</ref> Drilling stopped on 5 February 2011 at a depth of {{convert|3,720|m|ft|abbr=on}} so that the research team could make it off the ice before the beginning of the Antarctic winter season. The drilling team left by aircraft on 6 February 2011.<ref>{{cite news |first=B |last=Israel |title=Lake Vostok Drilling Mission Iced |date=7 February 2011 |url=http://www.ouramazingplanet.com/lake-vosotk-drilling-110207-1075/ |work=Our Amazing Planet |accessdate=7 February 2011 }}</ref>
By plan, the following summer, the team was to drill down again to take a sample of that ice and analyze it.<ref name="January 2011" /><ref name="Nature 469">{{cite journal |last=Schiermeier |first=Q |title=Race against time for raiders of the lost lake |journal=Nature |volume=469 |issue=7330 |pages=275 |url= |date=January 2011 |pmid=21248808 |doi=10.1038/469275a |bibcode=2011Natur.469..275S }}</ref> The Russians resumed drilling into the lake in January 2012 and reached the upper surface of the water on 6 February 2012.<ref name=Kaufman/><ref>{{cite news |first=D |last=Cressey |title='Too soon' to confirm success of Antarctic lake drilling |date=7 February 2012 |url=http://www.nature.com/news/too-soon-to-confirm-success-of-antarctic-lake-drilling-1.9986 |work=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |accessdate=8 February 2012 }}</ref> The researchers allowed the rushing lake water to freeze within the bore hole and months later, they collected ice core samples of this newly formed ice and sent to the Laboratory for Glaciology and Environmental Geophysics in Grenoble, France, for analysis.<ref name="Lagnado" />
===Biology results===
====United Kingdom and United States==== Scientists first reported evidence of microbes in the accretion ice in 1999.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.discovery.com/earth/lake-vostok-accretion-ice-life-130709.htm|title=Ice Above Lake Vostok Includes DNA From Animals|author=Becky Oskin|first=|date=9 June 2013|work=Our Amazing Planet|accessdate=10 July 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160315151107/http://news.discovery.com/earth/lake-vostok-accretion-ice-life-130709.htm|archive-date=2016-03-15|publisher=Discovery}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://science.nasa.gov/science-news/science-at-nasa/1999/ast10dec99_2|title=Exotic microbes discovered near Lake Vostok {{!}} Science Mission Directorate|last=|first=|date=1999-12-10|website=science.nasa.gov|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref> Since then, a different team led by Scott O. Rogers has been identifying a variety of bacteria and fungi from accretion ice (not from the subglacial water layer) collected during U.S. drilling projects in the 1990s.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Isolation of Microbes from Lake Vostok Accretion Ice |journal=Appl. Environ. Microbiol. |date=1 August 2008 |first=Tom |last=D'Elia |first2=Ram |last2=Veerapaneni |first3=Scott O. |last3=Rogers |volume=74 |issue=15 |pages=4962â4965 |url=http://aem.asm.org/content/74/15/4962.short |doi=10.1128/AEM.02501-07 |pmid=18552196 |pmc=2519340 |accessdate=7 July 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |title=Isolation of fungi from Lake Vostok accretion ice |journal=Mycologia |date=17 July 2009 |first=Tom |last=d'Elia |first2=Ram |last2=Veerapaneni |first3=Vincent |last3=Theraisnathan |first4=Scott O. |last4=Rogers |volume=101 |pages=751â763 |doi=10.3852/08-184 |issue=6 |pmid=19927741 }}</ref> According to him, this indicates that the lake below the ice is not sterile but contains a unique ecosystem. Then Scott Rogers published in July 2013 that his team performed [[nucleic acid]] ([[DNA]] and [[RNA]]) sequencing and the results allowed deduction of the metabolic pathways represented in the accretion ice and, by extension, in the lake. The team found 3,507 unique gene sequences, and approximately 94% of the sequences were from bacteria and 6% were from [[Eukarya]].<ref name="Shtarkman and KoÃ§er">{{cite journal |title=Subglacial Lake Vostok (Antarctica) Accretion Ice Contains a Diverse Set of Sequences from Aquatic, Marine and Sediment-Inhabiting Bacteria and Eukarya |journal=PLoS ONE |date=3 July 2013 |first=Yury M. |display-authors=4 |last=Shtarkman |first2=Zeynep A. |last2=KoÃ§er |first3=Robyn |last3=Edgar |first4=Ram S. |last4=Veerapanenimm |first5=Tom |last5=DâEliam |first6=Paul F. |last6=Morris |first7=Scott O. |last7=Rogers |volume=8 |issue=7 |pages=e67221 |url=http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0067221#close |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0067221 |pmid=23843994 |editor-last=Watson |editor-first=Michael |accessdate=7 July 2013 |bibcode=2013PLoSO...867221S |pmc=3700977}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nbcnews.com/science/antarcticas-hidden-lake-vostok-found-teem-life-6C10561955 |title=Antarctica's hidden Lake Vostok found to teem with life |first=Alan |last=Boyle |publisher=[[NBC News]] |date=8 July 2013 }}</ref> Taxonomic classifications (to genus and/or species) or identification were possible for 1,623 of the sequences. In general, the taxa were similar to organisms previously described from lakes, brackish water, marine environments, soil, glaciers, ice, lake sediments, deep-sea sediments, deep-sea thermal vents, animals and plants. Sequences from [[Aerobic organism|aerobic]], [[Anaerobic organism|anaerobic]], [[Psychrophile|psychrophilic]], [[Thermophile|thermophilic]], [[Halophile|halophilic]], [[Alkaliphile|alkaliphilic]], [[acidophile|acidophilic]], desiccation-resistant, [[autotroph]]ic, and [[heterotroph]]ic organisms were present, including a number from multicellular eukaryotes.<ref name="Shtarkman and KoÃ§er" />
However, microbiologist David Pearce of the University of Northumbria in Newcastle, UK, stated that the DNA could simply be contamination from the drilling process, and not representative of Lake Vostok itself. The old ice cores were drilled in the 1990s to look for evidence of past climates buried in the ice, rather than for life, so the drilling equipment was not [[Sterilization (microbiology)|sterilized]].<ref name="DNA analyses">{{cite news |author=Michael Marshall |title=Lake Vostok may boast a thriving ecosystem |date=8 July 2013 |url=https://www.newscientist.com/article/dn23832-lake-vostok-may-boast-a-thriving-ecosystem.html |work=New Scientist |accessdate=10 July 2013 }}</ref> Also Sergey Bulat, a Lake Vostok expert at the Petersburg Nuclear Physics Institute in Gatchina, Russia, doubts that any of the cells or DNA fragments in the samples would belong to organisms that might actually exist in the lake. He says that it is very probable that the samples are heavily contaminated with tissue and microbes from the outside world.<ref name="Nature 2013">{{cite journal |title=Claims of Lake Vostok fish get frosty response |journal=Nature |date=9 July 2013 |first=Quirin Schiermeier |doi=10.1038/nature.2013.13364 |url=http://www.nature.com/news/claims-of-lake-vostok-fish-get-frosty-response-1.13364 |accessdate=10 July 2013 |last1=Schiermeier }}</ref>
====Russia and France==== Russian and French scientists have been carrying out molecular DNA studies of the water from Lake Vostok that was frozen in the borehole, by constructing numerous [[Library (biology)|DNA libraries]],<ref name="Lagnado">{{cite news |first=Alice |last=Lagnado |title=Whatâs really inside Lake Vostok |date=2 January 2014 |url=http://voiceofrussia.com/uk/news/2014_01_02/What-s-really-inside-Lake-Vostok-8507/ |work=Voice of Russia |accessdate=16 January 2014 }}</ref> which are collections of fragments of DNA that allow scientists to identify which species of bacteria may belong to. Samples taken from the lake so far contain about one part of kerosene per 1000 of water, and they are contaminated with bacteria previously present in the drill bit and the kerosene drilling fluid.<ref name="Lagnado" /> So far, the scientists have been able to identify 255 contaminant species, but also have found an unknown bacterium when they initially drilled down to the lake's surface in 2012, with no matches in any international databases, and they hope it may be a unique inhabitant of Lake Vostok.<ref name="Lagnado" /><ref name="TDT-20130307">{{cite news |title=New life form found in Lake Vostok |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/antarctica/9915788/New-life-form-found-in-Lake-Vostok.html |date=7 March 2013 |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |accessdate=8 March 2013 |author=Staff }}</ref><ref name="LS-20130307">{{cite web |last=Howell |first=Elizabeth |title=New Type of Bacteria Reportedly Found in Buried Antarctic Lake |url=http://www.livescience.com/27737-new-bacteria-found-antarctic-lake.html |date=7 March 2013 |work=[[LiveScience]] |accessdate=8 March 2013 }}</ref> However, Vladimar Korolev, the laboratory head of the study at the same institution, said that the bacteria could in principle be a contaminant that uses keroseneâthe antifreeze used during drillingâas an energy source.<ref name="RT-20130308">{{cite news |author=Staff |title=Russian scientists discover unidentified bacteria in sub-glacial Lake Vostok |url=http://rt.com/news/lake-vostok-russia-bacteria-944/ |date=8 March 2013 |work=[[RT (TV network)]] |accessdate=8 March 2013 }}</ref><ref name="RBTH-20130309">{{cite news |author=Staff |title=No unfamiliar microorganisms found in Lake Vostok water - researcher |date=9 March 2013 |publisher=[[Russia Beyond the Headlines]] |url=http://rbth.ru/news/2013/03/09/no_unfamiliar_microorganisms_found_in_lake_vostok_water_-researcher_23670.html |work=[[Interfax]] |accessdate=10 March 2013 }}</ref>
Critics from the scientific community state that no valuable information can be obtained until they can test clean samples of lake water, uncontaminated by drilling fluid.<ref name="Lagnado" /> Regardless of the contamination issues, in May 2013 the drilling facility at the Russian Vostok Antarctic station was declared a historic monument as "the result of the recognition of the achievements of the Russian research of Antarctica by the international scientific community, and of the unique operations on opening the subglacial Lake Vostok performed by Russian scientists on February 5, 2012."<ref name="monument">{{cite news |author=Staff |title=Drilling facilities that pried open Antarctic Lake Vostok becomes monument |date=15 January 2014 |url=http://voiceofrussia.com/news/2014_01_15/Drilling-facilities-that-pried-open-Antarctic-Lake-Vostok-becomes-monument-1233/ |work=The Voice of Russia, TASS |accessdate=16 January 2014}}</ref>
In January 2015, the Russian press stated that Russian scientists have made a new "clean" borehole into Lake Vostok using a special 50-kilogram probe that collected about 1 liter of water not adulterated by the antifreezing fluid.<ref name="New bore 2015"/> It was predicted that the water would rise 30â40 m in the bottom part of the borehole, but in fact the water rose from the lake to a height of more than 500 m. In October of that same year, the work was suspended for that southern summer because of insufficient funding by the federal Russian government.<ref name="MoscowTimes2015">{{cite news |last=Staff |url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/russian-antarctic-expedition-halts-research-due-to-lack-of-funds/539033.html |title=Russian Antarctic Expedition Halts Research Due to Lack of Funds |work=The Moscow Times |location=Moscow |date=14 October 2015 |accessdate=2015-10-15 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.sciencemag.org/content/350/6260/494.summary Mysterious Antarctic lake will remain out of reach]. ''Science'' 30 October 2015. Vol. 350 no. 6260 p. 494 {{doi|10.1126/science.350.6260.494 }}</ref>
===Contamination due to drilling fluids=== The drilling project has been opposed by some [[Environmental movement|environmental groups]] and scientists who have argued that [[Ice drilling#Hot water and steam drills|hot-water drilling]] would have a more limited [[Environmental degradation|environmental impact]].<ref name="Discovery News">{{cite news |first=E |last=Niiler |title=Antarctic Drilling Plan Raises Concerns |date=9 February 2011 |url=http://news.discovery.com/earth/lake-vostok-antarctica-environment-110209.html |work=Discovery News |accessdate=10 February 2011 }}</ref> The main concern is that the lake could become contaminated with the antifreeze that the Russians used to keep the bore hole from refreezing. Scientists of the [[United States National Research Council]] have taken the position that it should be assumed that microbial life exists in Lake Vostok and that after such a long isolation, any life forms in the lake require strict protection from contamination.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://dels.nas.edu/resources/static-assets/materials-based-on-reports/reports-in-brief/subglacial_lakes_final.pdf |format=PDF |title=Exploration of Antarctic Subglacial |date=2007 |work=National Academy of Sciences |publisher=National Research Council |accessdate=9 February 2011 }}</ref>
The original drilling technique employed by the Russians involved the use of Freon and kerosene to lubricate the borehole and prevent it from collapsing and freezing over; {{convert|60|ST|MT|lk=on}} of these chemicals have been used thus far on the ice above Lake Vostok.<ref name="Morton" /> Other countries, particularly the United States and Britain, have failed to persuade the Russians not to pierce to the lake until cleaner technologies such as hot-water drilling are available.<ref name="sydney">{{cite news |first=A |last=Darby |title=Antarctic Treaty no match for national pride |date=8 February 2011 |url=http://www.smh.com.au/environment/conservation/antarctic-treaty-no-match-for-national-pride-20110209-1ameh.html |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |accessdate=9 February 2011 }}</ref> Though the Russians claim to have improved their operations, they continue to use the same borehole, which has already been contaminated with kerosene.<ref name="ASOC">{{cite web |url=http://www.asoc.org/issues-and-advocacy/antarctic-environmental-protection/lake-vostok |title=Antarctica's Lake Vostok Controversy |date=2010 |publisher=[[Antarctic and Southern Ocean Coalition]] |accessdate=10 February 2011}}</ref> According to the head of Russian Antarctic Expeditions, Valery Lukin, new equipment was developed by researchers at the [[Petersburg Nuclear Physics Institute]] that would ensure the lake remains uncontaminated upon intrusion.<ref name="January 2011" /> Lukin has repeatedly reassured other signatory nations to the Antarctic Treaty System that the drilling will not affect the lake, arguing that on breakthrough, water will rush up the borehole, freeze, and seal the other fluids out.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.currentscience.ac.in/Volumes/102/10/1355.pdf |format=PDF |title=Drilling at Lake Vostok by the Russians |first=Jaimini |last=Sarkar |publisher= |date= |accessdate=28 December 2012 }}</ref>
Some environmentalist groups remain unconvinced by these arguments. The [[Antarctic and Southern Ocean Coalition]] has argued that this manner of drilling is a profoundly misguided step which endangers Lake Vostok and other subglacial lakes in Antarctica (which some scientists are convinced are inter-linked with Lake Vostok).<ref name="appeal" /> The coalition has asserted that "it would be far preferable to join with other countries to penetrate a smaller and more isolated lake before re-examining whether penetration of Lake Vostok is environmentally defensible. If we are wise, the Lake will be allowed to reveal its secrets in due course."<ref name="appeal" />
Lukin claims that hot-water drilling is much more dangerous for the microbiotic fauna, as it would boil the living species, plus disturb the entire structure of water layers of the lake.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aif.ru/society/article/52592 |script-title=ru:ÐÐ·ÐµÑÐ¾ ÐÐ¾ÑÑÐ¾Ðº - "ÐºÑÑÐ¾ÑÐµÐº" ÐÐ°ÑÑÐ° Ð½Ð° ÐÐµÐ¼Ð»Ðµ? |language=Russian |trans-title= |last=ÐÐ°Ð½Ð¸Ð»ÐµÐ²Ð¸Ñ |first=ÐÐ»ÐµÐ½Ð° |publisher=[[Argumenty i Fakty]] |date=6 June 2012 |accessdate=25 December 2012 }}</ref> Additionally, hot-water drilling would have required more power than the Russian expedition could have generated at their remote camp.<ref name="Discovery News" /> However, the water samples obtained by the Russian team were heavily contaminated with drilling fluid, so they reported in May 2017 that it was impossible at this time to obtain reliable data on the real chemical and biological composition of the lake water.<ref>[http://sp.lyellcollection.org/content/early/2017/05/23/SP461.3 Chemical characteristics of the ice cores obtained after the first unsealing of subglacial Lake Vostok]. Irina Alekhina, Alexey Ekaykin, Alexey Moskvin and Vladimir Lipenkov. ''Geological Society'', London, Special Publications, 461, 24 May 2017. {{doi|10.1144/SP461.3}}</ref>

[[Image:Linienlaser mit Wechselobjektiven.jpg|thumb|Line laser with interchangeable lenses]]
{{Refimprove|date = November 2014}}A '''line laser''' is a [[laser]] modified to project a line rather than a point (e.g. [[laser pointer]]). This may be achieved by passing the beam through a [[cylindrical lens]] or a Powell lens.
Using multiple lasers, it is possible to project multiple lines for use with [[image processing]].
Depending on the application, line lasers can generate lines, crosses or other patterns. Civil engineering and interior design projects can use line lasers to measure the [[levelling]] of a small building site.
==Applications== [[File:4-quadrant ring light laser crosshairs.jpg|thumb|Laser alignment crosshairs projected by a ring light which is mounted to a stereo microscope; the crosshairs facilitate rapid component location when transitioning between microscope and direct viewing]] * [[Diffractive beam splitter]] * [[Calibration]] * [[Spirit level]] * [[David Laserscanner]] * [[Light section]] * [[Image processing]] * [[Machine vision]] * [[3D scanner]] * [[Laser scanning]] * [[Laser line level]] * [[Laser level]] * [[Surveying]]
