Mexico|url = http://www.motran.org/mexroads-extended.html}} [[Durango, Durango|Durango]] and [[Mazatlan]] are connected by [[Mexican Federal Highway 40|highway 40]], around 24 degrees north latitude. ==Geology== The Sierra Madre Occidental is a high plateau of volcanic rock that is eroded in areas to reveal a basement composed of [[plutonic]] and [[sedimentary]] rocks underlying the two groups of [[extrusive]] volcanics.{{cite web | title = Geology | publisher = Bronco Gold and Silver | url = http://broncogold.com/geology.html | accessdate = 15 March 2012 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120714155337/http://broncogold.com/geology.html | archivedate = 14 July 2012 | df = dmy-all }} The lower of these groups is a series of volcanic rocks formed by [[Lava|lava flows]]. The surface of the plateau is made up of a second series of volcanic [[ignimbrite]]s, covered mostly by clay rich organic [[soil]]s. Some [[intrusion]]s in the area have deposited [[ore]] veins that are commercially viable. The landscape was shaped after rock placement. Rivers [[Erosion#Rivers and streams|cut]] valleys into the plateau, following [[Fold (geology)|folds]] in the rocks. Rock have been broken off of the slopes, forming rocky sides. The bedrock is covered by the clay rich soils, except in eroded areas, where water carries away deposits leaving a stony surface. ===Geological history=== The basement is thought to be Older North American basement, especially in the North, and a number of different [[accreted terrane]]s, which are mostly covered by [[Cenozoic]] volcanism.{{cite web|title = The Guerrero Composite Terrane of western Mexico: Collision and subsequent rifting in a supra-subduction zone|last = Centeno-Garcia| last2 = Guerrero-Suastegui|last3 = Talavera-Mendoza| year = 2008| url = http://www.ugr.es/~agcasco/igcp546/Geochron/pdf/mexico/2008Centeno-Garciaetal.pdf}} The northern extent of the Sierra Madre is the CortÃ©s Terrane, although the northern extreme of this contains a small portion of the Carborca Terrane. Some of the northern end may also be underlain by a [[Precambrian]] basement placed around the same time as the [[Grenville Orogeny]].{{cite journal| title = Effects of basement composition and age on silicic magmas across an accreted terrane-Precambrian crust boundary, Sierra Madre Occidental, Mexico | last = Albrecht | first = Achim | last2 = Goldstein | first2 = Steven | date = 1 July 2000 | journal = Journal of South American Earth Sciences | volume = 13 | issue = 3 | pages = 255â273| doi = 10.1016/S0895-9811(00)00014-6| bibcode = 2000JSAES..13..255A }} Some of this area has a series of [[Paleozoic]] sedimentary sequences from a [[Sedimentary rock#Sedimentary environments|deep marine]] environment underlying it, which considered by some to be part of the Cotes Terrane and by others to be [[Allochthon|transported]].{{cite web | title = Magmatism and tectonics of the Sierra Madre Occidental and its relation with the evolution of the western margin of North America | last = Ferrari | first = Luca | last2 = Valencia-Moreno | first2 = Martin | last3 = Bryan | first3 = Scott | year = 2007 |url=http://www.geociencias.unam.mx/~luca/Ferrari%20et%20al%202007.pdf| publisher = Geological Society of America | accessdate = 7 January 2012}} In some areas distinct sedimentary rocks can be identified by shallow-water [[Silurian]] and [[Mississippian age|Mississippian]] sedimentary rocks underlying deep-water [[Pennsylvanian (geology)|Pennsylvanian]] and [[Permian]], which are divided by Mississippian [[rhyolite]]. The Permian clastics contain some [[Detritus (geology)|detrital]] rock that sit alongside low-grade metamorphosed sedimentary and volcanic rocks with serpentinite.{{Cite journal|title = Closing the ocean between the Precordillera terrane and Chilenia: Early Devonian ophiolite emplacement and deformation in the SW Precordillera|last = Davis|first = J.S.|last2 = Roeske|first2 = S.M.|first3 = W.C.|last4 = Snee|first4 = L.W.|year = 2000|last3 = McClelland}} South of the Cortes and Carborca Terranes is the San JosÃ© de GarcÃ­a Terrane, which is a combination of Cretaceous arc volcanics and [[Clastic rock#Clastic metamorphic and igneous rocks|volcaniclastics]], which may be thrusting over the Cortes terrane.{{cite web|title = Geology and Tectonic Evolution of the Western Guerrero Terraneâa Transect from Puerto Vallarta to Zihuatanejo, Mexico|last = Centeno-Garcia|first = Elena|last2 = Corona-Chavez|first2 = Pedro|last3 = Talavera-Mendoza|first3 = Oscar|last4 = Iriondo|first4 = Alex|year = 2003|url = http://www.geociencias.unam.mx/~rmolina/documents/centenoetal2003.pdf}} The southern part of the range is made up of the Guerrero Composite Terrane, a large body, which is actually a complex of five different subterranes, although not all of these are within the main body of the Sierra Madre. However, the terrane is mostly covered by volcanics and sedimentary deposits, so it is only visible where erosion has revealed it.{{cite web| title = Isotopic Studies of the Guerrero Composite Terrane, West-Central Mexico: Implications for Provenance of Crustal Rocks and Genesis of Ore Metals|last = Potra|first = Adriana|year = 2011| url = http://digitalcommons.fiu.edu/etd/371/}} The main subterranes of the Guerrero Composite Terrane that are within the Sierra Madre are the Tahue and Zihuatanejo terranes. Dividing the Guerrero Terrane from the rest of the Sierra Madre terranes is a boundary that is thought to represent the Early Cretaceous Arperos Basin,{{cite journal|title = Terranes of Mexico Revisited: A 1.3 Billion Year Odyssey|last = Keppie|first = J.|journal = International Geology Review|volume = 46|pages = 765â794|year = 2004|url = http://www.geologia.uson.mx/academicos/grijalva/antologiageolmex/archivos%20pdf/precambrico%20sur%20mex/terrenos%20de%20mexico%20(2004).pdf|doi = 10.2747/0020-6814.46.9.765|issue = 9|bibcode = 2004IGRv...46..765K|access-date = 21 October 2012|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20130411202412/http://www.geologia.uson.mx/academicos/grijalva/antologiageolmex/archivos%20pdf/precambrico%20sur%20mex/terrenos%20de%20mexico%20(2004).pdf|archive-date = 11 April 2013|dead-url = yes|df = dmy-all}} a [[Oceanic basin|marine basin]] which separated the island arc that came to form the Guerrero terrane from the accretions that came to form the Sierra Madre terrane.{{cite journal|title = The Early Cretaceous Arperos basin: an oceanic domain dividing the Guerrero arc from nuclear Mexico evidenced by the geochemistry of the lavas and sediments|last = Freydier|first = C.|last2 = Lapierra|first2 = H.|last3 = Ruiz|first3 = J.|last4 = Tardy|first4 = M.|last5 = Martinez|first5 = J.|last6 = Coulon|first6 = C.|journal = Journal of South American Earth Sciences|volume = 13|year = 2000|pages = 325â336|url = http://www.geociencias.unam.mx/~rmolina/documents/freydier-et-al.pdf|doi = 10.1016/S0895-9811(00)00027-4|issue = 4â5|bibcode = 2000JSAES..13..325F}} It contains a lower formation made up of [[pillow basalt]]s with [[Breccia#Volcanic|pillow breccias]], tuffs, and [[shale]]s underlying a group of [[Pelagic zone|pelagic]] limestones, [[Siliceous ooze|oozes]], and [[turbidite]]s. Covering the southern basement are sedimentary and [[Metamorphic rock|metamorphised]] sedimentary rocks containing [[argillite]], [[limestone]],{{cite web | title = Geology of the western Mexican Volcanic Belt and adjacent Sierra Madre Occidental and Jalisco Block | last = Ferrari | first = Luca | last2 = Pasquare | first2 = Giorgio | last3 = Venegas-Salgado | first3 = Saul | last4 = Romero-Rios | first4 = Francisco | publisher = "Geological Society of America" | year = 1999}} [[Greenschist|volcanic schist]], [[slate]], and [[greywacke]] which were exposed in the canyon of the Santiago River. Near these sediments late [[Oligocene]] to early [[Miocene]] [[granite]] and [[granodiorite]] [[Igneous rock#Intrusive|intrusive]] bodies occur. A possible cause of this is that these bodies were roof pendants which were uplifted by [[pluton]]s. Mesozoic limestone also occurs in northern portion of the mountains, mostly from the Cretaceous. [[File:Durango volcanic field.jpg|thumb|left|The Durango Volcanic field]] Towards the end of the [[Cretaceous]], the [[Laramide orogeny]] increased the activity of [[magmatism]] in the area, forming the first major igneous series in the area. The igneous series are made up of formations of plutonic and volcanic rock, which would later be exposed. [[Interbedding|Interbedded]] with these rocks are sedimentary deposit rocks. In the center of the range, some of these rock have been deformed by [[tectonics|tectonic forcing]] that occurred at the same time. The southern part of the range contains none of the volcanism that is apparent in the northern range. These formations ended in the [[Paleocene]]. [[Eocene]] volcanism formed a series of [[andesite|andesitic]] and [[rhyolite|rhyolitic]] formations in the area, with spatial and temporal variations throughout. Most of the [[gold]] and [[silver]] deposits are also in these rocks. [[File:Sierra.madre.occidental.volcanics.JPG|thumb|An example of the ignimbrite units]] In the [[Oligocene]], ash flows became the predominant deposit of the area, with interbedded lava flows between. These ash flows began the second series of high magmatism formations. The [[Mid-Tertiary ignimbrite flare-up|ignimbrite flare-up]] formed a series of ignimbrite formations, layered one atop another, that are sometimes broken by lava flows. The ignimbrite formations in this area cover the largest area of any known series, with ten [[caldera]]s identified in the province.{{cite web | title = Basin and Range Fissure-Source Origin for Voluminous Ignimbrites of the Sierra Madre Ocidental, Mexico | last = Aguirre-Diaz | first = Gerardo | last2 = Labarthe-Hernandez | first2 = Guillermo | last3 = Torres | first3 = Ramon | year = 2002 | url = http://gsa.confex.com/gsa/2002CD/finalprogram/abstract_34577.htm | accessdate =15 March 2012}} Three of these calderas are in Copper Canyon. The lava has formed a series of [[mafic]] rock that form the Southern Cordilleran Basaltic Andesite Suite.{{cite web | title = Correlation between the Tomochic and Copper Canyon Areas, the Sierra Madre Occidental, Chihuahua, Mexico | last = Swanson | first = Eric | year = 2002 | url = http://gsa.confex.com/gsa/2002SC/finalprogram/abstract_33078.htm | accessdate =15 March 2012}} The [[tuff]]s are above a thick formation of lava rock. Around five or six units have been identified, mostly around the Copper Canyon area. These tuffs have allowed wide-ranging correlation with formations in other geographical areas, for example [[Death Valley]].{{cite web| title = Upper Neogene Stratigraphy and Tectonics of Death Valley â a review | last = Knott | first = J.R. | last2 = Sarna-Wojcicki | first2 = A.M. | last3 = Machette | first3 = M.N. | last4 = Klinger | first4 = R.E. | year = 2005 | url = http://geology.fullerton.edu/jknott/images/ESR%20Paper.pdf | accessdate =15 March 2012}} During the [[Miocene]], three periods of volcanism marked separate events in the Sierras. Each period is marked by different volcanic processes.{{cite journal|title = Variation of Cenozoic Extension and Volcanism across the Southern Sierra Madre Occidental Volcanic Province, Mexico|last=Nieto-Samaniego|first=Ãngel|last2=Ferrari|first2=Luca|last3=Alaniz-Alvarez|first3=Susana|last4=Labarthe-HenÃ¡ndez|first4=Guillermo|last5=Rosas-Elguera|first5=JosÃ©|journal=Geological Society of America Bulletin|year=1999|volume=111|issue=3|pages=347â363|url=http://gsabulletin.gsapubs.org/content/111/3/347.full.pdf|accessdate=17 February 2013|doi = 10.1130/0016-7606(1999)111<0347:VOCEAV>2.3.CO;2}} The first was a continuation of the Oligocene flare-up, which lasted through the early Miocene. This may be a distinct second occurrence of the same process, placing [[Silicic|silica-rich]] lava above Oligocene rocks. Also in the early Miocene more intermediate [[Basaltic andesite]]s occur along faults and in grabens. Beginning in the early Miocene and continuing into the middle, an arc of andesite was placed during the [[Gulf of California Rift Zone|spreading]] of the [[Gulf of California]]. The [[Basin and Range Province#Geology|basin and range-style faulting]] of the [[Serravallian|middle-late Miocene]] took place at the same time as the placement of [[alkali basalt]]s, In the westernmost slopes mafic dikes formed. These events have also been linked to the subduction of the [[Farallon Plate]].{{cite journal|title = Ignimbrite flare-up and deformation in the southern Sierra Madre Occidental, western Mexico: Implications for the late subduction history of the Farallon plate| last = Ferrari|first = Luca|last2 = Lopez-MartÄ±nez|first2 = Margarita|last3 = Rosas-Elguera|first3 = Jose|journal = Tectonics|volume = 21|issue = 4|year = 2002|url = http://www.geociencias.unam.mx/~luca/Ferrarietal2002.pdf|doi = 10.1029/2001TC001302|pages = 17â1|bibcode=2002Tecto..21.1035F}} Episodes of volcanism continued into the [[Quaternary]]. ===Structures=== The Sierras are believed to be a thick core covered by volcanics and eroded by numerous rivers. Some have suggested that the basement of the mountains have numerous intrusions made by mafic magma. The mountains are made up at the surface of large-scale ignimbrite sheet which have been incised by rivers flowing from rainfall in the mountains.{{ Cite journal | title = Post-Oligocene river incision, Southern Sierra Madre Occidental | last = Montgomery | first = David | last2 = Lopez-Blanco | first2 = Jorge | year = 2003 | url = http://gis.ess.washington.edu/grg/publications/pdfs/Mexico_paper.pdf | accessdate =20 March 2012|journal=Geomorphology |volume=55 |issue=1â4|pages= 235â247 | doi = 10.1016/S0169-555X(03)00142-9 }}{{Cite conference |conference= 20th Field Conference, New Mexico Geological Society |title= Notes on the Geomorphology and Late Cenozoic Geology of Northwestern Chihuahua | last = Hawley | first = John | year = 1969 | url = http://nmgs.nmt.edu/publications/guidebooks/downloads/20/20_p0131_p0142.pdf | accessdate =20 March 2012}} The surface of the plateau is almost exclusively from the second series of flows causing the rock that is most visible to be ignimbrites with lava flow layers. The region has a general [[Strike and dip|strike]] from just west of north to just south of east. [[Fault (geology)|Faults]] in the area tend to be younger than the upper volcanics, excluding those associated with calderas, but do occur in distinct periods. The large faults along the eastern slope have caused the slope to be made up of large [[escarpment]]s that face into the interior [[Structural basin|basins]]. These faults are commonly covered by [[alluvium]] and [[basalt]], making them difficult to discern, but can be found in certain [[fault block]]s. [[Graben]]s have formed in the north, and some of these are filled with volcanic and sedimentary floors, and long [[Depression (geology)|depressions]] have formed in the southern Sierra Madre.{{cite journal|title = Fissure ignimbrites: Fissure-source origin for voluminous ignimbrites of the Sierra Madre Occidental and its relationship with Basin and Range faulting | last = Aguirre-Diaz | first = Gerardo | last2 = Labarthe-Hernandez | first2 = Guillermo | journal = Geology | volume = 31 | issue = 9 | pages = 773â776 | doi=10.1130/G19665.1|year = 2003 | bibcode = 2003Geo....31..773A }} The faulting decreases in the center of the range where the faults are mostly small [[Dip-slip faults|normal faults]], but increases once again on the western slope. In fact, the major normal faults tend to diverge around the center of the core and join at either end. Some of these faults may have allowed ignimbrites to [[Fissure vent|erupt]] from the surface, and so there may be some association between the ignimbrite occurrence and faults; this can be used to find out [[Structural geology|information]] about different kinds of basement rock present. There are two faults dividing the Sierra Madre from the central [[Mexican Plateau]]. The more southern one is the northâsouth Aguascalientes fault extending {{convert|150|km|mi}} from Altos de Jalisco to near Zacatecas, where it joins the more northern northwestâsoutheast trending San LuisâTepehuanes fault extending from Guanajuato to Durango.{{cite web|title = Mesa Central of MÃ©xico: Stratigraphy, structure, and Cenozoic tectonic evolution|last = Nieto-Samaniego|first = Angel|last2 = Alaniz-Ãlvarez|first2 = Susana|last3 = Camprubi|first3 = Antoni|year = 2007|url = http://www.geociencias.unam.mx/~afns/index_files/Nieto-SamaniegoEtAl_MesaCentral_SPE422_02.pdf}} The southern boundary of the Sierra Madre Occidental with the Jalisco block is a series of folds, [[Thrust fault|thrust]], and left [[Strike-slip fault|lateral]] faults date from the middle Miocene. This may be evidence for a left [[transpression]]al [[shear zone]]. The area between this boundary and the Aguascalientes fault is filled with numerous grabens and half-grabens, as well an eastâwest left shear zone, the El Roble shear zone. At the west end of these grabens and half-grabens are the Pochotitan and the more northerly San Pedro fault systems, which form the western boundary of the faults in the southern mountains. In the north there is an unknown boundary between the Cortes Terrane and the Guerrero Composite Terrane. Some theorize that this is a section of the MojaveâSonora Megashear, but this theory is not universally accepted; however, the Megashear is important, and, in fact, is necessary for [[Historical Geology|reconstructions]] of the opening of the Gulf of California, as of 2003.{{cite journal|title = Structure and kinematics along a segment of the Mojave-Sonora megashear: A strike-slip fault that truncates the Jurassic continental magmatic arc of southwestern North America|last = Campbell|first = Patricia|last2 = Anderson|first2 = Thomas|journal = Tectonics|volume = 22|issue = 7|year = 2003|url = http://www.agu.org/journals/tc/tc0306/2002TC001367/|doi = 10.1029/2002TC001367|pages = n/a|bibcode=2003Tecto..22.1077C}} ===Mineral deposits=== On a smaller scale, mineral deposits are distributed in formations of the Sierra Madre, although the [[Ore genesis|events]] that placed these deposits vary throughout the mountains. The Guerrero composite terrane contains many of the economic deposits, often found in ore bodies younger than the Cretaceous. Gold and silver deposits most commonly occur in the altered andesites of the early volcanics, typically these deposits are between 30 and 50 million years old.{{cite journal| title = Cenozoic mineral deposits and subduction-related magmatic arcs in Mexico| last = Damon|first = Paul|journal = GSA Bulletin| volume = 93|pages = 533â544|date = June 1982|url = http://bulletin.geoscienceworld.org/content/93/6/533.full.pdf| doi = 10.1130/0016-7606(1982)93<533:CMDASM>2.0.CO;2| last2 = Foster| first2 = C. Thomas| last3 = Damon| first3 = Paul E.| issue = 6| year = 1982}} These are believed to be caused by later [[intrusion]]s into the early flows. Fissure-vein deposits have been divided into two groups of [[Fracture (geology)|fissure]] [[Vein (geology)|vein]] deposits, which are divided geographically into an eastern and western series. In the east, the gold and silver are accompanied by [[lead]] and [[zinc]]. In the south, the [[BolaÃ±os Municipality|BolaÃ±os]] mine district is contained with the BolaÃ±os Graben.{{cite journal|title = Geology, Tectonic Environment, and Structural Controls in the San Martin de Bolafios District, Jalisco, Mexico|last = Scheubel|first = Frank|last2 = Clark|first2 = Kenneth|last3 = Porter|first3 = Elise|journal = Economic Geology|volume = 83|issue = 8|pages = 1703â1720|year = 1988|url = http://econgeol.geoscienceworld.org/content/83/8/1703.short|accessdate = 23 October 2012|doi = 10.2113/gsecongeo.83.8.1703}} Some also occur as epithermal deposits. Also, some gold occurs along with [[copper]] in Cenozoic iron-oxide [[Skarn#Ore deposits|skarn]] and replacement deposits along the Pacific. In addition to gold and silver and their related deposits, [[tin]], [[iron]], and [[Mercury (element)|mercury]] occur, sometimes in later units, mostly in later volcanics, and [[Molybdenum]] occurs in the mountains, often along with older copper deposits or in oligocene deposits in the east. The belt of tin deposits resides mostly within the eastern slopes from Durango to Guanajuato. In these areas, tin occurs in rhyolitic ignimbrites in many, possibly over 1000,{{cite journal|title = Petrology and geochemistry of rhyolites associated with tin mineralization in northern Mexico|last = Huspeni|first = Jeffrey|last2 = Kesler|first2 = Stephen|last3 = Ruiz|first3 = Joaquin|last4 = Tuta|first4 = Zane|last5 = Sutter|first5 = John|last6 = Jones|first6 = Lois|journal = Economic Geology|volume = 79|issue = 1|year = 1984|pages = 87â105|url = http://econgeol.geoscienceworld.org/content/79/1/87.short|doi = 10.2113/gsecongeo.79.1.87}} small deposits of [[cassiterite]]. Typically these deposits are divided from overlying ignimbrites by breccia, which may also contain ore. Many of these are thought to be [[Epithermal|hydrothermal deposits]] To the east of these units is a belt of more mercury deposits, followed by another belt of [[manganese]] deposits, although these deposits are mostly limited to Chihuahua and Hidalgo. Iron occurs in three different regions placed by different mechanisms. Along the Pacific there the numerous skarn and replacement deposits mentioned above with relation to gold. Iron occurs in Durango in the form of [[magnetite]] lava flows, which are often surrounded by smaller [[hematite]] deposits, thought to be ash flows. There is also a belt of iron deposits further east. ===Soil=== Most soil in the mountains is covered by an [[Organic matter|organic]] rich layer over layers rich in [[clay]].{{Cite journal | title = Influence of soil surface features and vegetation on runoff and erosion in the Western Sierra Madre (Durango, Northwest Mexico) | last = Descroix | last2 = Viramontes | last3 = Vauclin | last4 = Gonzalez Barrios | last5 = Esteves | year = 2000 | doi=10.1016/S0341-8162(00)00124-7 | first1 = L | first2 = D | first3 = M | first4 = J.L | first5 = M | journal = CATENA | volume = 43 | issue = 2 | pages = 115â135}} Soils are commonly [[phaeozems]] that are up to {{convert|100|cm|in}}. Some soils are [[cambisols]] that are less than {{convert|2|m|ft}} deep and well [[Drainage|drained]].{{cite conference|title = Soil degradation and desertification in the Western Sierra Madre of Mexico|last = Gonzales-Barrios|last2 = Descroix|last3 = Viramontes|last4 = Anaya |conference= 17th WCSS 14â21 August|year=2002 |location = Thailand}} Due to the high clay contents, which block water from being absorbed into the soil, larger rock particles in the soil help reduce runoff and soil losses from erosion. Areas that are covered in stone are known as [[lithosols]] and make up most of the remaining surface in the mountains, especially on upper slopes. The last major soil type are [[vertisols]] which are thin mineral poor soils. Soils at higher elevations experience more [[Leaching (pedology)|leaching]], due to increased rainfall.{{ cite journal | title = The Distribution of Evergreen and Deciduous Trees Relative to Soil Type: An Example from the Sierra Madre, Mexico, and a General Model | last = Goldberg | first = Deborah | journal = Ecological Society of America | volume = 63 | year = 1982 | pages = 942â951 | jstor = 1937234 }} [[Acid]]ic soils may have lower [[calcium]] content, leading to lower plant soil quality. Soils along the eastern slopes have increased organic content and a clay heavy layer that is developed more than those of the more arid eastern lands. The thickness of soil layers also increases. Problems with soil degradation have been aggravated by the cultivation of drug crops, leading to [[deforestation]] of many areas.{{cite web | title = Highlands and Drylands: Mountains a source of resilience in arid regions | last = Pajares | first = Pedro | year = 2011 | url = http://www.fao.org/docrep/014/i2248e/i2248e00.pdf| accessdate = 18 October 2012}} Other problems include [[overgrazing]], which has led to terracing from cattle paths and the formation of a [[soil crust]], and [[soil acidification]], which poses a risk to some grasslands as of 2002. ==Climate== The climate varies considerably between the northern and southern extents of this long mountain range. Seasonal variations also occur due to the presence of large bodies of warm water delivering warm damp air from each side of the range. This region undergoes a seasonal variety with two wet seasons, including a summer [[monsoon]], and two dry seasons each year. ===Temperature, Pressure, and Wind=== Air pressure changes in Northwestern Mexico and the [[Southwest United States]] are the main causes of seasonal variation in the Sierra Madre. A [[high pressure area]] that rests over the mountains in the winter begins to move north of the mountains into [[New Mexico]] during the month of June.{{cite web | title = The North American Monsoon | publisher = National Weather Service | url = http://www.cpc.ncep.noaa.gov/products/outreach/Report-to-the-Nation-Monsoon_aug04.pdf | accessdate =7 January 2012}} The high pressure begins to breakdown and move south during September or October; however, the breakdown is usually at a slower pace than the movement north. This high pressure belt is associated with the mechanics that form the [[Bermuda High]].{{cite web | title = Solar radiation and Ã©vapotranspiration in northern Mexico estimated from remotely sensed measurements of cloudiness | last = Garatuza-Payan | first = Jaime | last2 = Pinker | first2 = Rachel | last3 = Watts | first3 = Christopher | date = December 2001 | url = http://iahs.info/hsj/460/hysj_46_03_0465.pdf | accessdate = 15 March 2012 }}{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The climate in the mountains is mild. Summer temperatures maintain a constant level. Maximum temperatures are typically in July at around 31 C with average temperatures on the order of 16 C during this same period. Mean annual temperatures are between {{convert|55|-|65|F|C}} above {{convert|6000|ft|m}}.{{cite web|title = Integrated Environmental Plan for the Mexican-U.S. Border Area|year = 1992|url = http://pdf.usaid.gov/pdf_docs/PNABM228.pdf|accessdate = 21 October 2012}} Below freezing temperatures can occur in the higher mountains, with [[precipitation (meteorology)|precipitation]] occurring as snowfall certain times of year.{{cite web | title = Sierra Madre Occidental pine-oak forests | date = 1 December 2006 | url = http://www.eoearth.org/article/Sierra_Madre_Occidental_p | accessdate =15 March 2012}} During the summer monsoon, [[wind]] patterns undergo large-scale changes. In May there is very little large-scale wind current through the mountains, most circulates around the mountains, although [[Sea breeze|onshore flow]] is present.{{Cite journal | title = The Mexican Monsoon | last = Douglas | first = Michael | last2 = Maddox | first2 = Robert | last3 = Howard | first3 = Kenneth | last4 = Reyes | first4 = Sergio | year = 1992 | url = http://climateknowledge.org/NA_precipitation/Douglas_Mexican_Monsoon_JClim_1993.pdf | accessdate =19 March 2012 |doi=10.1175/1520-0442(1993)006<1665:TMM>2.0.CO;2 | volume = 6 | pages = 1665â1677 | journal = Journal of Climate | issue = 8}} As the high pressure moves north, air is pulled off the Gulf of Mexico, bringing easterly winds aloft to the mountains. On the east slope of the mountain daytime upslope winds flow to the crest, where the flow joins westerly winds.{{Cite journal| title = Multistage moisture transport into the interior of northern Mexico during the North American summer monsoon | last = Fawcett | first = Peter | last2 = Stalker | first2 = James | last3 = Gutzler | first3 = David | year = 2002 | doi=10.1029/2002GL015693| journal = Geophysical Research Letters| volume = 29| issue = 23 | pages = 9â1 | bibcode=2002GeoRL..29.2094F}} The mountains cause convection during the following monsoon season, during which nocturnal winds at low levels in the atmosphere move moisture overnight. After the high pressure breaks down, wind patterns return to those prior to the monsoon season. === Precipitation and Humidity=== Precipitation varies on both annual and seasonal scales in the Sierra Madre. Annual differences in regional climate are associated with the [[El NiÃ±o-Southern Oscillation]] with El NiÃ±o years leading to a wetter climate.{{cite web | title = Influence of Climate and Land Use on Historical Surface Fires in Pine-Oak Forests, Sierra Madre Occidental, Mexico | last = Heyerdahl | first = Emily | last2 = Alvarado | first2 = Ernesto | url = http://www.fs.fed.us/rm/pubs_other/rmrs_2003_heyerdahl_e001.pdf | year = 2003 }} Monsoon rains come to the Sierra Madre in June, as the high pressure area moves north, leading to wet summer seasons. This causes east winds bringing [[moisture]] from the [[Gulf of Mexico]]. On the western side of the mountains, which are affected by the largest change in precipitation between the [[dry season]] and monsoon season, in the monsoon season rainfall can exceed {{convert|30|cm|in|abbr=on}} in a single month. The southern region receives more of the rainfall than the northern. Much of this precipitation occurs as [[tropical storms]]. As the high pressure over New Mexico breaks down, rainfall in the Sierra Madre ends. Because of the monsoon, the summer accounts for the majority of rainfall in the area. The spring and fall dry season separate out a weaker wet season in the winter. In addition to increasing in the southern ranges of the mountains, rainfall increases in the higher elevations of the Sierra Madre Occidental. [[Humidity]] in the mountains varies at wide levels as does rainfall. In the early morning before dawn, the air is almost saturated (often over 90% [[relative humidity]]) near the mountain tops with low clouds over the range. Lower in the range, air is not as near saturated in the morning.{{cite journal | title = The Diurnal Cycle of Clouds and Precipitation along the Sierra Madre Occidental Observed during NAME-2004: Implications for Warm Season Precipitation Estimation in Complex Terrain | last = Nesbitt | first = Stephen | last2 = Gochis | first2 = David | last3 = Lang | first3 = Timothy | year = 2007 | url = http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/pdf/10.1175/2008JHM939.1 | accessdate =19 March 2012 | doi=10.1175/2008JHM939.1 | journal = Journal of Hydrometeorology | volume = 9 | issue = 4 | pages = 728â743| bibcode = 2008JHyMe...9..728N }} Seasonal variation in humidity is also present with average May and June relative humidity around 50%, with 25% possible during the day. Also during the day, relative humidity drops and cloud levels rise as temperatures rise. The humidity of the range is also influenced by the same seasonal changes as rainfall. In the dry season [[dew point]]s are low at high elevations (500 hPa), around {{convert|-22|Â°C|Â°F|abbr=on}} in the south of the range, and {{convert|-24|and|-26|Â°C|Â°F|abbr=on}} in the north in May. In June, dew points begin to increase from the May levels up to {{convert|-20|Â°C|Â°F|abbr=on}} in the north and {{convert|-16|Â°C|Â°F|abbr=on}} in the south. By July these dew points are at {{convert|-14|Â°C|Â°F|abbr=on}} throughout the range. The range allows higher dew points throughout these periods than the surrounding low lands. This rise in humidity accompanies the monsoon. ==Ecology== [[File:Sierra Madre Occidental....jpg|thumb|left|[[Sierra Madre Occidental pine-oak forests]]]] The mountains create a diverse setting for plants and animals by creating a different set of conditions from the surroundings. The [[Sierra Madre Occidental pine-oak forests]] are found at elevations of {{convert|1500|-|3000|m|ft|abbr=on}} throughout the range,{{WWF ecoregion |id=na0302 |name=Sierra Madre Occidental pine-oak forests|accessdate=10 October 2010}} but the forests in the mountains vary by elevation and place in the range. This ecoregion is noted for its high [[biodiversity]] and large number of [[Endemism|endemic]] species,{{cite journal | title = Prominence of the Sierra Madre Occidental in the Biological Diversity of Mexico | last = Bye | first = Robert | year = 1994 | journal = "Biodiversity and the Management of the Madrean Archipelago" | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=4Jib08R5_8kC&pg=PA118 | isbn = 9780788183867}} and for allowing some species to extend their [[Range (biology)|range]]. ===Flora=== The [[Dominance (ecology)|dominant]] plants vary across the range, and the habitat that they present varies from scattered [[woodland]] to both [[deciduous]] and [[Pinophyta|coniferous]] forest. The elevation and latitude in the range are the major determining factors in the dominant plants. [[Oak]]s dominate the lower reaches of the mountains, where stands grow down to about {{convert|1000|m|ft|abbr=on}}. Some oak species even continue into the surrounding ecosystems.{{cite web | title = Center for Sonoran Desert Studies | year = 2006 | accessdate =15 March 2012 | url = http://www.desertmuseum.org/programs/alamos_vegetation.htm}} In the Western slopes of the range, [[cloud forest]] also occurs, mostly on mid-elevation slopes with little exposure to wind or sun{{cite journal | title = Mapping Mexico's Mountain Forests | last = Kremsa | first = V | last2 = Varela | first2 = S | journal = "Forests in Sustainable Mountain Development" | pages = "9â12"}} in the southern end of the range.{{cite journal | title = Historical relationships of the Mexican cloud forests | last = Vega | first = Isolda | last2 = Ayala | first2 = Orthon | last3 = Organista | first3 = David | last4 = Morrone | first4 = Juan | journal = "Journal of Biogeography" | volume = 26 | pages = "1299â1305" | url = https://unam.academia.edu/JuanJMorrone/Papers/1089503/Historical_relationships_of_the_Mexican_cloud_forests_A_preliminary_vicariance_model_applying_Parsimony_Analysis_of_Endemicity_to_vascular_plant_taxa | accessdate =16 March 2012 | doi = 10.1046/j.1365-2699.1999.00361.x | year = 1999 | issue = 6}} At higher elevations [[pine]]s begin to grow alongside the oaks, and pines begin to dominate the oaks at higher elevations.{{cite web | title = Major Biotic Communities | accessdate = 15 March 2012 | url = http://www.biopark.org/sierramadre.html | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20111230000153/http://www.biopark.org/sierramadre.html | archivedate = 30 December 2011 | df = dmy-all }} At high elevations and in the north, [[Temperate broadleaf and mixed forest|mixed conifer forests]] become the dominant ecosystem. These forests are composed primarily of pines and [[fir]]s, which begin to grow at these elevations.{{cite journal | title = Trees of the Northern Sierra Madre Occidental and the Sky Islands of Southwestern Arizona | last = Felger | first = Richard | last2 = Johnson | first2 = Matthew | year = 1994 | journal = "Biodiversity and the Management of the Madrean Archipelago" | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=4Jib08R5_8kC&pg=PA118 | isbn = 9780788183867}} There are also [[Alpine tundra|grasslands]] on some mountain tops, surrounded by the forest that occur in those areas. Plants in the area typically have large responses to the change in climate with each season. Monsoon season is the largest of these effects, with leaf buds following only a few months after the rains begin. Flowering season occurs in the months preceding the summer monsoon. This is only the peak flowering season, with plants flowering throughout the year. Due to the early flowering, [[fruit]] is ripe and [[seed]]s are dispersed at the beginning of the rains. There are also areas where plants have little response to the seasons, particularly those areas that experience moist conditions, caused by the elevations. These plants may maintain leaves through times when other areas are in the dry season, during which most deciduous trees have no leaves.{{Cite journal | title = Environmental control of flowering periodicity in Costa Rican and Mexican tropical dry forests | last = Borchert | first = Rolf | last2 = Meyer | first2 = Stefanie | last3 = Felger | first3 = Richard | last4 = Porter-Bolland | first4 = Luciana | year = 2004 | doi=10.1111/j.1466-822X.2004.00111.x | journal = Global Ecology and Biogeography | volume = 13 | issue = 5 | pages = 409â425}} ===Fauna=== The mountains are often a [[Habitat corridor|corridor]] for species allowing more diversity in the area, by combining species from different regions. Animals typically associated with arid and mountainous habitats share the mountains with species associated with habitats further south.{{cite web|title = Northern Sierra Madre Occidental and Its Apachian Outliers: A Neglected Center of Biodiversity|last = Felger|first = Richar|last2 = Wilson|first2 = Michael|year = 1994|url = http://www.fs.fed.us/rm/pubs_rm/rm_gtr264/rm_gtr264_036_059.pdf|accessdate = 23 October 2012}} There are many carnivorous and omnivorous mammals native to the area, although several are extirpated or are part of threatened populations. The [[Mexican wolf]]'s range in the mountains is limited to the foothills of Durango{{cite thesis|title = The Political Ecology of Deforestation in the Sierra Madre Occidental of Chihuahua|last=Gingrich|first=Randall|publisher=University of Arizona|year=1993}} or may have been extirpated{{cite journal|title = A checklist of the mammals (Mammalia) of Chihuahua, Mexico|last = Lopez-Gonzalez|first=Celia|last2 = Garcia-Mendoza|first2=Diego|journal=Check List|volume=8|issue=6|pages=1122â1133|year=2012}} the black bear population is small, and the [[Mexican grizzly bear]] that once resided here{{cite book|last1=Wright|first1=William|title=The Grizzly Bear|date=1913|publisher=University of Nebraska Press|location=Lincoln, NE|page=32|edition=Repriint of 1913}} is confirmed extinct.{{cite journal|title = Probable occurrence of a Brown Bear (Ursus Arctos) in Sonora, Mexico, in 1976|last = Gallo-Reynoso|first = Juan-Pablo|last2 = van Devender|first2 = Thomas|last3 = Reina-Guerrero|first3 = Ana Lilia|last4 = Egido-Villarreal|first4 = Janitzio|last5 = Pfeiler |first5 = Edward|journal = Southwestern Naturalist|volume = 53|issue = 2|pages = 256â260|date = June 2008|url = https://www.academia.edu/891138/Probable_occurrence_of_a_brown_bear_Ursus_arctos_in_Sonora_Mexico_in_1976|accessdate = 2 February 2013|doi = 10.1894/0038-4909(2008)53[256:POOABB]2.0.CO;2|year = 2008}} [[North American jaguar|Jaguar]]s and [[ocelot]]s are also now rare. On the other hand, [[North American cougar|mountain lion]] and [[bobcat]] are more common.{{cite web|title = Spatial and Trophic Ecology of Mountain Lions (Puma concolor) and Bobcatys (Lynx rufus) in the Sierra San Luis, Sonora|last=Lopez Gonzalez|first=Carlos}} On the eastern slopes there are [[American badger]], [[coyote]] and [[gray fox]] that live across the mountains. Native ungulates include the [[white tailed deer]], [[mule deer]], and [[collared peccary]]. Rodents and lagomorphs include the [[eastern cottontail]], which lives in the forests of the western slopes,{{cite book|title = Distribution and Systematics of the Rabbits (Sylvilagus) of West-Central Mexico|last=Diersing|first=Victor|last2=Wilson|first2=Don|publisher=Smithsonian Institution Press|year=1980}} [[cliff chipmunk]], [[rock squirrel]], [[Mexican fox squirrel]], and various species of [[Cricetidae]].{{cite journal|title = Rodents of the state of Sonorao, Mexico|last=Hafner|first=David|journal=Rodents of Sonora|pages=23â34|year=2012}} [[Raccoon]]s, [[hog-nosed skunk]], and [[hooded skunk]] live in the mountains. The [[white-nosed coati]] lives on the western slopes, and the [[ring-tailed cat]] lives throughout. Many species of [[bat]]s live in the mountains also. A variety of [[lizard]]s live in the area and surroundings. The [[Tarahumara frog]] lives in the oak and pine stands preferring moving water to pools. The southern extent of the [[Sonoran mountain kingsnake]]'s range is the Chihuahuan desert into the mountains. Other snakes and frogs live in the mountains, and many species live in the western slopes.{{cite book |title=A Field Guide to Western Reptiles and Amphibians |last=Stebbins |first=Robert |authorlink=Robert C. Stebbins |year=2003 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9JznHN2VFzkC |publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt |isbn=978-0-395-98272-3}} Birds frequent the mountains, some as a [[Bird migration|migratory path]] and others as [[Indigenous (ecology)|native species]]. The migratory birds often use the area to the west as an [[overwintering]] area, and migrate north along the western slopes.{{cite web|title = Migration Stopover Ecology of Western Avian Populations: A Southwestern Migration Workshop|last = Hazelwood|first = Rob|year = 2005|url = http://www.fort.usgs.gov/products/publications/21409/21409.pdf|accessdate = 23 October 2012}} In the northern canyons birds may be divided into different [[habitat]]s, or more specifically, the different types of forest, leading to differences in range by altitude.{{cite web|title = Birds of the Barranca de Cobre Region of Southwestern Chihuahua, Mexico|last = Stager|first = Kenneth|year = 1954|url = http://sora.unm.edu/sites/default/files/journals/condor/v056n01/p0021-p0032.pdf|accessdate = 23 October 2012}} Some of this difference by altitude may even extend the range of some species, enabling [[Tropics#Tropical ecosystems|tropical species]] to use the mountain valleys for migration. Bird species [[endemism|endemic]] to the Sierra Madre Occidental include [[tufted jay]], the "gray-eared" subspecies of [[red warbler]], [[eared quetzal]], [[thick-billed parrot]], and formerly included the [[imperial woodpecker]], which now may be extinct. The rivers and streams of the range contain some of the southernmost [[trout]] populations in North America. These populations may be native, although this is not universally accepted.{{cite web|title = Conservation of Mexican Trout and the Discovery, Status, Protection, and Recovery of the Conchos Trout, the First Native|last = Hendrickson|first = Dean|year = 2006|url = http://www.utexas.edu/tmm/tnhc/fish/research/truchas_mexicanas/pub/reports/Hendrickson_etal_2007_conservation_Mexican_trout.pdf|accessdate = 19 February 2013}} [[Invasive species|Invasive]] fish compete with the native species which has been a cause of concern among researchers, along with concerns about the effects of logging on these species. ===Surroundings=== The [[Sonoran Desert]] is found in the northwestern foothills at {{convert|1000|-|2000|m|ft|abbr=on}}.{{WWF ecoregion |id=na1310 |name=Sonoran desert|accessdate=10 October 2010}} The [[Chihuahuan Desert]] is found to the northeast and east, the [[Meseta Central matorral]] and [[Central Mexican matorral]] to the southeast, and the [[Sinaloan dry forests]] to the west and southwest. These lower elevations are usually graded into by a stand of [[Tropical and subtropical dry broadleaf forests|tropical deciduous forest]], which has a large portion of flora made up of [[flowering plant]]s and [[legume]]s. These flowering plants are mostly from the genus ''[[Bursera]]''.{{Cite journal | title = Timing the origin and expansion of the Mexican tropical dry forest | last = Becerra | first = Judith | year = 2005 | pmid = 16033871 | doi = 10.1073/pnas.0409127102 | volume = 102 | issue = 31 | pages = 10919â23 | pmc = 1182403 | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America| bibcode = 2005PNAS..10210919B }} The [[ecotone]], made up of the tropical deciduous forest, is commonly sparsely populated, sometimes only by small stands of trees. It may be referred to as [[Oak savanna|savanna]]. ===Preservation=== [[Conservation (ethic)|Preservation efforts]] in the modern day, include those from [[Edwin Bustillos]].{{cite web | title = Goldman Environmental Prize | url = http://www.goldmanprize.org/node/87 | accessdate = 6 November 2007 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20071012193905/http://www.goldmanprize.org/node/87 | archivedate = 12 October 2007 | df = dmy-all }} Other groups work to protect animal species in the area including [[Conservation International]].{{cite web | title = Sierra Madre de Chiapas | publisher = Conservation International | accessdate =15 March 2012 | url = http://www.conservation.org/where/north_america/mexico/pages/sierra_madre_de_chiapas.aspx}} [[Basaseachic Falls National Park]] is a [[List of national parks of Mexico|national park]] in the mountains containing the highest [[waterfall]]s in the country. Since 1979 there has also been a national park in the transition between the Chihuahuan Desert and the Sierra, the [[Cumbres de Majalca National Park]].{{cite journal|title = Plant Associations of Cumbres de Majalca National Park, Chihuahua, Mexico|last = Estrada-Castillon|first = Eduardo|last2 = Jurado|first2 = Enrique|last3 = Navar|first3 = Jose|last4 = Jimenez-Perez|first4 = Javier|last5 = Garza-Ocanas|first5 = Fortunato|journal = The Southwestern Naturalist|volume = 48|issue = 2|date = June 2003|pages = 177â187|doi = 10.1894/0038-4909(2003)048<0177:PAOCDM>2.0.CO;2|editor1-last = Lauver|editor1-first = Chris|year = 2003}} Additionally there are reserves such as La Michilia in the southern Sierra Madre,{{cite web|title = La Michilia|date = 8 March 2011|url = http://www.unesco.org/mabdb/br/brdir/directory/biores.asp?mode=all&code=MEX+02|accessdate = 23 October 2012}} or the Tutuaca reserve in western Chihuahua, which was established in 2000 under a new system of management.{{cite web|title = Fire regime in a conservation reserve in Chihuahua, Mexico|last = Fule|first = Peter|last2 = Villanueva-DÃ­az|first2 = JosÃ©|last3 = Ramos-GÃ³mez|first3 = Mauro|year = 2004|url = http://library.eri.nau.edu/gsdl/collect/erilibra/import/FuleEtal.2005.FireRegimeInAConservation.pdf|accessdate = 23 October 2012}} ==People and history== [[File:Tarahumaras1.jpg|thumb|upright|An early picture of Tarahumara]] The mountains are home to several indigenous nations speaking [[Uto-Aztecan languages]], including the [[Tarahumara]] in the central portion of the range, the [[Huichol people|Huichol]] in the southern part of the range, and the [[Tepehuan]]es in the eastern slopes.{{cite book | title = Mexico and the United States | last = Stacy | first = Lee | year = 2003 | isbn=0761474021|publisher=Marshall Cavendish Corp}} ===Prehistory=== [[Archaic period in the Americas|Archaic]] cultures are known to have inhabited the Sierra Madre along with the rest of the surrounding lands, but little is known of the culture, although it does vary between the northern and southern extremes of the range.{{cite_journal | title = Prehistory of Chihuahua and Sonora, Mexico | last = Phillips | first = David | journal = Journal of World Prehistory | year = 1989 | volume = 3 | issue = 4| pages = 373â401 | doi=10.1007/BF00975109}} The [[Agriculture in Mesoamerica|agrarian]] [[Chalchihuites| Chalchihuites Culture]] began as farming communities around the first century AD and remained small communities until 300 AD when new agricultural techniques caused a large growth in population until around 500 AD.{{cite book | title = Mexico's Indigenous Past | last = Austin | first = Alfredo | last2 = LujÃ¡n | first2 = Leonardo | year = 2001 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=tzB4rfXObCwC&printsec=frontcover|publisher=University of Oklahoma Press|isbn=978-0-8061-3723-0}} This culture began to decline in the ninth century. The [[Mogollon culture]] has been described in the northern foothills. Sites date the emergence of the culture to around 900 AD and abandonment to around 1000â1100 AD.{{cite book | title = Archaeological Excavations in the Northern Sierra Madre Occidental, Chihuahua and Sonora, Mexico | last = Lister | first = Robert | year = 1958 | url = https://archive.org/stream/archaeologicalex00list#page/n5/mode/2up | accessdate =18 March 2012}} During the [[Mesoamerica#Postclassic|period estimated]] for Mogollon abandonment, the Rio Sonora culture began [[Agriculture in Mesoamerica|agricultural developments]] along the Rio Sonora and rivers flowing into it. This culture produced [[pottery]] and lived in [[Pit-house|pit houses]], until 1150 to 1200 when they began to construct surface dwellings.{{cite web | title = Archaeology of Northwest Mexico: A Review | last = Phillips | first = David | date = 4 January 2011 | url = http://www.unm.edu/~dap/nwm/w-flank.html | accessdate =18 March 2012}} Construction of these houses ended around AD1550. ===Spanish Sierra Madre=== In 1554 [[Francisco de Ibarra]] came to [[Durango]] and began to settle the area.{{cite web |title=Durango-History |year=2012 |url=http://www.history.com/topics/durango |accessdate=14 April 2012}} He would explore the western coast and cross the Sierra Madre in 1564.{{cite web |title=Historic Native Peoples of Texas |last=Foster |first=William |year=2011 |url=http://www.utexas.edu/utpress/excerpts/exfoshis.html |accessdate=14 April 2012}} Early Spanish influence in the area came from the new silver mines, the first of which was established in 1567 at Santa Barbara.{{cite web |title=Indigenous Chihuahua: a Story of War and Assimilation |last=Schmal |first=John |year=2004 |url=http://www.houstonculture.org/mexico/chihuahua.html |accessdate=14 March 2012}} As sites opened for mining, [[Mission (Christianity)|missionaries]] came to the areas and had a strong presence by 1595.{{cite book |title=Cycles of conquest: the impact of Spain, Mexico, and the United States on the Indians of the Southwest, 1533â1960 |last=Spicer |first=Edward |year=1962 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ymw4seEFGmQC&pg=PR12 |publisher=University of Arizona Press |isbn=978-0-8165-0021-5 |pages=12â }} The first meeting with the Tarahumara came in 1607, when a missionary went up the valley to meet them. Opposition to the missionaries built up, leading to the [[TepehuÃ¡n Revolt]]. This revolt began in 1616 in the town of Santa Catarina de Tepehuanes in [[Durango]]{{cite conference |title=The Black Robes of New Spain |conference= American Catholic Historical Association |date=29 December 1934 |accessdate=14 March 2012 }} and lasted for two years. The discovery of silver at [[Parral, Chihuahua |Parral]] in 1631 led to the northern limit of settlement moving into Tarahumara lands. The [[Society of Jesus|Jesuits]] renewed missionary activity in the 1630s, with a new program that increased in scope until around 1650. Tarahumara moved further into the mountains in order to escape the conditions. A [[Native American disease and epidemics#Origins of Native American Disease|smallpox epidemic]] caused a revolt in 1645.{{cite journal |title=Rural Work in Nueva Vizcaya: Forms of Labor Coercion on the Periphery |last=Deeds |first=Susan |journal=Hispanic American Historical Review |volume=69 |issue=3 |year=1989 |url=http://faculty.utep.edu/LinkClick.aspx?link=deeds.pdf&tabid=12199&mid=151855 |accessdate=14 April 2012 |doi=10.2307/2516301 |page=425|jstor=2516301 }} In 1648 a revolt arose, primarily among the Tarahumara. A [[drought]] caused a pair of revolutions in 1650 and 1652. The last major revolt began in March 1690 among the Tarahumara and ended in 1698.{{cite book |title=Native resistance and the Pax Colonial in New Spain | last=Schroeder |first=Susan }} [[Demand (economics)|Demands]] from [[Conscription|labor drafts]] increased in the 1720s, placing a new pressure on missions. Criticism of the Jesuits rose in the 1730s with complaints of Jesuit Commerce, which was established by mission stores.{{cite book | title = Defiance and Deference in Mexico's Colonial North: Indians Under Spanish Rule in Nueva Vizcaya | last = Deeds | first = Susan|year=2003 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=5Nut8Z2mFoEC&pg=PA136|publisher=University of Texas Press|isbn=978-0-292-78230-3|pages=136â }} In 1767, Jesuits were [[Suppression of the Society of Jesus|expelled]] from New Spain, ending the mission program. A new colonial official [[JosÃ© de GÃ¡lvez]] came to New Spain and established new laws that caused a boom in silver mining activity in the 1770s.{{cite journal | title=Mexican Silver-Mining in the Eighteenth Century: the Revival of Zacatecas |last=Brading |first=D. |journal="The Hispanic American Historical Review" |volume=50 |issue=4 |date=November 1970 |jstor=2512308}} After the [[Apaches|Apache]] faced heightened resistance to raiding from the Spanish in Chihuahuan, they moved down to the Sierra Madre in 1794.{{cite web |title=Ethnographic overview and assessment of Chiricahua National Monument and Fort Bowie National Historic Site |last=Rushforth |first=Scott |url=http://www.cefns.nau.edu/Orgs/CPCESU/current/documents/NMSUCP-007FinalReport.pdf |date=July 2010 |accessdate=14 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120620220704/http://www.cefns.nau.edu/Orgs/CPCESU/current/documents/NMSUCP-007FinalReport.pdf |archivedate=20 June 2012 |df=dmy-all }} By 1800, raiding had essentially ended. ===Mexican Sierra Madre=== [[File:Villa close up.jpg|thumb|upright|[[Pancho Villa]]]] After leaving San Carlos in fall of 1881 Geronimo and other Apache moved to the mountains, and became known as the ''Nednai'', sometimes referred to as the "Pinery Apache" or "Bronco Apache".{{cite journal|title = Chiricahua Apache Homeland in the Borderland Southwest|last = Arreola|first = Daniel|journal = Geographical Review|volume = 102|issue = 1|date = 1 March 2012|doi=10.1111/j.1931-0846.2012.00133.x|pages = 111â131}} From here they would raid Sonora and the surrounding land until general [[George Crook]] entered the mountains in 1883 to discuss Geronimo's return. Geronimo eventually surrendered in 1886. [[Pancho Villa]] fled to the mountains in 1894, becoming a bandit.{{cite web | title = http://militaryhistory.about.com/od/army/p/panchovilla.htm | last = Hickman | first = Kennedy | url = http://militaryhistory.about.com/od/army/p/panchovilla.htm | accessdate =14 April 2012}} ====19th century==== Railroads came to the area starting in the 1880s and 1890s, which allowed many old mines in the region to reopen at a profit.{{cite book |title=The Mexican Revolution: Counter-revolution and Reconstruction |last=Knight |first=Alan |year=1986 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RLwB1ZSXkM0C |publisher=University of Nebraska Press |isbn=978-0-8032-7770-0}} Since most of the railroads were American, the foreign influence led to unrest among the people living in the mountains, causing the Tomochic rebellion in 1892.{{cite book |title=Revolutionary Mexico: The Coming and Process of the Mexican Revolution |last=Hart |first=John |year=1987 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ooj7djTCiHsC&pg=PR9 |publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-06744-8 |page=9}} In addition to the railroads, canals were constructed in the 1890s in the Yaqui and Mayo river valleys.{{cite book | title = Agrarian populism and the Mexican state: the struggle for land in Sonora | last = Sanderson | first = Steven|year=1981 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=sXvjHWFI1_AC|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-04056-4}} However, these canal projects failed due to the resistance that the natives of the valleys put up against the projects.{{cite book |title=Sonora Its Geographical Personality |last=West |first=Robert |year=1993 |url= |publisher=University of Texas Press |isbn=978-0-292-78560-1 |page=106}} Loggers began arriving in the mountains in the late 1800s. In response to the new industry, the Tarahumara moved further into the canyons. ====20th century==== The [[Mexican Revolution|1910 revolution]] began in Chihuahua and spread over the mountains throughout the winter of 1910â1911.{{cite book |title=In the Shadow of the Mexican Revolution: Contemporary Mexican History, 1910â1989 |last=CamÃ­n |first=HÃ©ctor |last2=Meyer |first2=Lorenzo |year=1993 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BUsu0Xky6iwC&pg=PR7 |publisher=University of Texas Press |isbn=978-0-292-79233-3 |pages=7â }} Silver mines were forced to make payments to the rebels, but were allowed to continue operating. General [[John J. Pershing|John Pershing]] began to follow [[Pancho Villa]] in 1916 and entered the mountains, however, he received no information from the local population.{{cite book |title=The Mexican Revolution, 1910â1940 |last=Gonzales |first=Michael |year=2002 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=se17aQLbKioC&pg=PA67 |publisher=UNM Press |isbn=978-0-8263-2780-2 |pages=67â}} By 1919 the raids subsided and Villa returned peacefully to the foothills. In order to construct irrigation projects in the lowlands below the valleys, irrigation projects were never completed in the Sonoran hills; instead, the Yaqui River was dammed in the 1930s. Dams continued to be constructed in the 1940s and 1950s on the Yaqui River and its tributaries with the largest reservoir, behind the Oviachic dam, completed in 1952. Dams were also constructed on the Mayo river. Because of the dams, soil conditions fell, and more works were required to improve soil quality. The mountain range was crossed by the [[Ferrocarril Chihuahua al Pacifico]] [[Rail transport|railroad]], completed in 1961. The railroad went up for sale in 1996, but no transaction was ever completed.{{cite web |title=Access issues in Latin America railroads: what could Europe learn/avoid? |last=Campos |first=Javier |year=2000 |accessdate=15 March 2012 |url=http://www.vatt.fi/file/vatt_publication_pdf/k245.pdf#page=213 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130502064432/http://www.vatt.fi/file/vatt_publication_pdf/k245.pdf#page=213 |archive-date=2 May 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} ==See also== {{Commons category|Sierra Madre Occidental|

==Phone numbers formats== Telephone numbers in [[Peru]] are made of:
===Mobile telephony=== * Nine digits for mobile numbers across the country. The first digit is always the number nine: '''9xx xxx xxx'''
===Fixed (land) lines=== * Seven digits in the Metropolitan Area of [[Lima]] and [[Callao]] * Six digits in the rest of the country
==Area codes== Peruvian area codes for each [[Political division of Peru#Current division|region]] (national subdivision) are 2 digits long except for Lima and Callao. On 1 March 2003 new codes were established.
The following is a list of the area codes in Peru:<ref>[http://www.mtc.gob.pe/portal/avm2/codigos.pdf Peru Area Codes chart: Ministry of Transports and Communications] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110104160930/http://www.mtc.gob.pe/portal/avm2/codigos.pdf |date=2011-01-04 }}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Area code ! Region |- | 1 | [[Lima Region|Lima]] and [[Callao Region|Callao]] |- | 41 | [[Amazonas Region|Amazonas]] |- | 43 | [[Ancash Region|Ancash]] |- | 83 | [[ApurÃ­mac Region|ApurÃ­mac]] |- | 54 | [[Arequipa Region|Arequipa]] |- | 66 | [[Ayacucho Region|Ayacucho]] |- | 76 | [[Cajamarca Region|Cajamarca]] |- | 84 | [[Cusco Region|Cusco]] |- | 67 | [[Huancavelica Region|Huancavelica]] |- | 62 | [[HuÃ¡nuco Region|HuÃ¡nuco]] |- | 56 | [[Ica Region|Ica]] |- | 64 | [[JunÃ­n Region|JunÃ­n]] |- | 44 | [[La Libertad Region|La Libertad]] |- | 74 | [[Lambayeque Region|Lambayeque]] |- | 65 | [[Loreto Region|Loreto]] |- | 82 | [[Madre de Dios Region|Madre de Dios]] |- | 53 | [[Moquegua Region|Moquegua]] |- | 63 | [[Pasco Region|Pasco]] |- | 73 | [[Piura Region|Piura]] |- | 51 | [[Puno Region|Puno]] |- | 42 | [[San MartÃ­n Region|San MartÃ­n]] |- | 52 | [[Tacna Region|Tacna]] |- | 72 | [[Tumbes Region|Tumbes]] |- | 61 | [[Ucayali Region|Ucayali]] |}
==Mobile phone calls within Peru (Mobile Virtual Area)== From September 4, 2010, a national Mobile Virtual Area<ref>Peru Mobile Virtual Area, Ministry of Transports and Communications {{es icon}} {{cite web |url=http://www.mtc.gob.pe/portal/avm2/avm.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110104161116/http://www.mtc.gob.pe/portal/avm2/avm.pdf |archivedate=2011-01-04 |df= }}</ref> was created meaning that all mobile numbers in Peru are ''non-geographical'' (not attached to any geographical region but instead to the new MVA). In addition to that all mobile numbers across the country turned to nine digits long: '''9xx xxx xxx'''.<ref>ITU: [http://www.itu.int/oth/T02020000A6/en national numbering plans - Peru] visited September 11, 2010</ref>
The following instructions are valid '''across the country''':<ref>International dialing instructions: Ministry of Transports and Communications {{cite web |url=http://www.mtc.gob.pe/portal/avm2/ejemplosdellamadas.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101214101247/http://www.mtc.gob.pe/portal/avm2/ejemplosdellamadas.pdf |archivedate=2010-12-14 |df= }}</ref>
===Calls from mobile to mobile=== 9xx xxx xxx (just dial the 9-digit number)
===Calls from mobile to landline=== 0 + area code + phone number Example on how to call to Piura: 0 + 73 + 388351
===Calls from fixed line to mobile=== 9xx xxx xxx (just dial the 9-digit number)
==Domestic calls within Peru==
===Calls from fixed line to landline=== Call to a number in the same area: just dial the phone number
Call to a number in another area ('''domestic long distance'''): 0 + area code + phone number.
==International long distance==
===Calling Peru from abroad===
====Calling a fixed line==== +51 + area code + phone number Where the plus sign (+) represents the international access code of the country you are calling from.
From North America: 011 + 51 + area code + phone number
Example: * Calling a fixed line in Lima: '''011 51''' '''1''' 1234567 * Calling a fixed line in Cusco: '''011 51''' '''84''' 123456
From Europe or most APAC countries: 00 + 51 + area code + phone number
====Calling a mobile number==== +51 + 9-digit mobile number The mobile virtual area eliminates the use of area code for mobile numbers.
===Calling abroad from Peru=== In Peru, when making an international call you may choose a carrier for international calls '''different from your usual carrier/provider''' according to the rates carriers offer to attract callers. This system is known as "call by call" (in Spanish "Llamada por llamada") as each call can be made with a different carrier and is available to both fixed lines and mobile phones. Each carrier uses a 4-digit prefix (format 19XX).
====International dialing format==== This is the standard format in Peru for making calls abroad from fixed lines and mobile phones: 19XX + 00 + country code + area code + phone number
Carriers: * Americatel: 1977<ref>Americatel website {{es icon}} [http://www.americatel.com.pe/contenidos.php?ic=12]</ref> * Claro: 1912<ref>Claro website {{es icon}} [http://www2.claro.com.pe/PortalClaroWeb/portal/PortalClaro.portal?_nfpb=true&_windowLabel=InstitucionalController_1&_pageLabel=INS&menuItem=0.4.9&esPromocion=false&idAbuelo=04#wlp_InstitucionalController_1]</ref> * IDT: 1914<ref>IDT website {{es icon}} [http://www.1914.com.pe/]</ref> * Convergia: 1960 * Movistar: 1911<ref>Movistar website {{es icon}} {{cite web |url=http://www.movistar.com.pe/Archivos/Atencion%20al%20Cliente/1673/index.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-12-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101208043413/http://www.movistar.com.pe/Archivos/Atencion%20al%20Cliente/1673/index.html |archivedate=2010-12-08 |df= }}</ref> * Nextel: 1990 (valid only for Nextel customers) * Viettel : 2014
It is '''mandatory''' to choose a 19XX carrier when calling internationally from a fixed line.
If you are calling internationally from a mobile phone you have the option not to use the 19XX prefix. You may dial starting with the "+" symbol +country code + area code + phone number and the international call will go through your provider's network.
===Example calls=== From Peru to USA/Canada: * From fixed line or mobile phone: 19XX + 00 + 1 + area code + phone number * From mobile phone (2Â° alternative): +1 + area code + phone number (your call will go through your usual provider's network)
==Special numbers== *103 is the telephone information number *105 is the Police Emergency Number *117 is the Ambulance number *116 is the Fire number
